fields.content: This composer used an English horn solo over muted strings to begin the Romanza third movement of his Symphony No. 5. An intermezzo is surrounded by two marches in a suite by this composer that quotes tunes such as "Seventeen Come Sunday." He wrote an overture to Aristophanes's play The Wasps and used a harp to imitate the Westminster chimes in his second symphony. This composer called for a string quartet, a chamber string orchestra, and a full-size string orchestra in a piece based on the Renaissance melody "Why fum'th in fight." A soaring violin solo depicts the upward motion of the title bird in a piece by this man based on George Meredith's poem The Lark Ascending. For 10 points, name this composer of fantasias on "Greensleeves" and a theme of Thomas Tallis.

For 10 points, name this composer of fantasias on "Greensleeves" and a theme of Thomas Tallis.

fields.content: This composer married Adeline in 1897 and served as a lieutenant in the Royal Artillery during World War I. His style's French influence is debated, and his Fifth Symphony, completed in 1943, contrasted sharply with its predecessor. His final symphony, the Ninth, premiered in 1958, months before his death, and he composed a work based on Shakespeare's "The Merry Wives of Windsor". On the fiftieth anniversary of his death, two documentaries about him were released. For 10 points, name this early 20th century English composer.

On the fiftieth anniversary of his death, two documentaries about him were released.
For 10 points, name this early 20th century English composer.

fields.content: This composer's first symphony, which includes a wordless soprano solo, was inspired by a collection of poems by Walt Whitman. This composer of the Sea Symphony also wrote a piece for string orchestra that was inspired by a theme by Thomas Tallis. This composer, who served as the musical editor for The English Hymnal, included a setting of the "Old 100th" in his music for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. For 10 points, name this British composer of Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis and The Lark Ascending.

fields.content: Due to public scrutiny, this act was reversed a week after it happened to Sri Lankan author Tissa Balasuriya. Though this process can occur immediately or latae sententiae, Canon 1425 states that it usually is administered ferendae sententiae by a panel of three judges. It is often said that an interdict is a form of this process applied to a whole polity. This act draws from Matthew 18, which says to treat those who ignore the church as "a Gentile and a tax-gatherer." This act was used as a threat in Leo X's bull Exsurge Domine, and may occur if one violates the "sacred species" by desecrating a consecrated host, or commits other grave sins. For 10 points, name this process in which the Catholic Church bans an individual from receiving the sacraments.

fields.content: The leadership of a stake typically decides this action for a Melchizedek priesthood holder. The West Shore UU Church's policy on this action was a model for several churches by the late 20th century. It deprives individuals of rights like sacraments, but they remain bound by law; reconciliation can restore these rights. It bars individuals from ministerial functions and sacraments, but not governance. If the "Arranging Brethren" fear this action may cause ecclesia division, they may seek a third party ecclesia for "refellowship". In Judaism, it signifies total community exclusion. The apostle's warning against company with a man is questioned if it refers to this action. For 10 points, name this religious penalty involving church expulsion.

fields.content: This practice was first formalized in the 4th century Council of Antioch, and it was later used against the Monophysites and Nestorians. The most severe form of this practice, known as "anathema," was used against the Patriarch of Constantinople, Michael Cerularius, in the Great Schism of 1054. This practice was famously used against Henry IV in the Investiture Controversy by Pope Gregory VII, leading to the Walk to Canossa. For 10 points, name this practice in which a person is officially excluded from participation in the sacraments and services of the Christian Church.

fields.content: An ammonium and sulfate salt of this metal named for Mohr is frequently used in titrations. The first attempted synthesis of fulvalene accidentally created a molecule with an atom of this metal at its center. An enzyme in the Krebs cycle named aconitase has a catalytic center with atoms of this metal and sulfur arranged in a cube. The first synthesized metallocene contained an atom of this metal at its center. This is the lightest element that cannot be used in stellar fusion without a cost in energy, or a supernova will occur. The mineral pyrite contains two sulfur atoms and an atom of this metal, and is commonly referred to as fool's gold. For 10 points, identify this metal found in ferrocene, whose oxide is rust.
clue_list: An ammonium and sulfate salt of this metal named for Mohr is frequently used in titrations.
The first attempted synthesis of fulvalene accidentally created a molecule with an atom of this metal at its center.

The first synthesized metallocene contained an atom of this metal at its center.
This is the lightest element that cannot be used in stellar fusion without a cost in energy, or a supernova will occur.
The mineral pyrite contains two sulfur atoms and an atom of this metal, and is commonly referred to as fool's gold.
For 10 points, identify this metal found in ferrocene, whose oxide is rust.

fields.content: This element's (II) compounds are prone to oxidation to their (III) forms in air. Its storage in human cells is strictly regulated, with its ions never "free". It's found in enzymes and proteins, often with heme groups, involved in biological oxidations and transport. A form of this element is used in cutlery and hospital equipment. Rich dietary sources include red meat, lentils, beans, poultry, fish, leaf vegetables, tofu, chickpeas, and molasses. During smelting, its molten slag floats atop the denser molten form, separated via furnace apertures. Its lower mantle mineral phase is often called magnesiowüstite. For 10 points, name this pervasive element symbolized as Fe.
clue_list: This element's (II) compounds are prone to oxidation to their (III) forms in air.
Its storage in human cells is strictly regulated, with its ions never "free".
It's found in enzymes and proteins, often with heme groups, involved in biological oxidations and transport.

Rich dietary sources include red meat, lentils, beans, poultry, fish, leaf vegetables, tofu, chickpeas, and molasses.
During smelting, its molten slag floats atop the denser molten form, separated via furnace apertures.
Its lower mantle mineral phase is often called magnesiowüstite.
For 10 points, name this pervasive element symbolized as Fe.

fields.content: This element is the primary component of the mineral taconite, which is processed into pellets in the Mesabi Range. The Haber-Bosch process requires a catalyst made from this element to produce ammonia. This element is found in the core of the Earth due to its high density, and it is the final element produced in the core of a massive star before it undergoes a supernova. Hemoglobin uses this element to transport oxygen in the blood. For 10 points, name this element with symbol Fe.
clue_list: This element is the primary component of the mineral taconite, which is processed into pellets in the Mesabi Range.
The Haber-Bosch process requires a catalyst made from this element to produce ammonia.

Hemoglobin uses this element to transport oxygen in the blood.
For 10 points, name this element with symbol Fe.

fields.content: A leading far-right figure in this country has championed an apocalyptic war to remake its continent in books like Foundations of Geopolitics and The Fourth Political Theory. The lead singer of this country's oldest rock band, Time Machine, was sanctioned in 2014 for supporting "fascism." This home of VTB Bank has been heavily criticized by the former head of Yukos from his exile in Switzerland. This country funds foreign militias like the Sparta Brigade and Rapid Response Team Batman in the Donbass region of a neighboring country, where Euromaidan protesters decried its influence on Viktor Yanukovych. For 10 points, identify this country that annexed Crimea from Ukraine, led by Vladimir Putin.

fields.content: A 1991 coup attempt aimed at preserving the Soviet Union led to the end of the Communist Party in this country. Since the 21st century, its economic growth has been bolstered by higher domestic consumption and political stability. Its Finance Minister Alexei Kudrin implemented a prudent macroeconomic policy, storing excess income in a Stabilization Fund. This federation and semi-presidential republic's constitution designates the President as head of state and the Prime Minister as head of government. CSKA Moscow and Zenit St Petersburg, clubs from this country, won the UEFA Cup in 2005 and 2008. For 10 points, name this largest country by land area.

fields.content: A leader from this country was the subject of a 2003 opera by Elena Firsova, who was inspired by his "Testament," a political will and testament. This country's leader initiated the Oprichnina, a policy of mass repression, public executions, and confiscation of land from boyars. The Time of Troubles, a period of political crisis, occurred in this country after the death of the childless Feodor I. The Romanov dynasty began its 300-year rule in this country after the Time of Troubles. For 10 points, name this country ruled by Ivan the Terrible.

fields.content: In 1961, this country received a diplomatic note calling for military consultations on defense against "Germany and her allies," as per the FCMA Treaty. The German-trained Jaegers made up the White Guards during this country's civil war. Yelena Bonner founded a watch group to monitor compliance with Article VII of an agreement signed in this country, which called for "respect for human rights." During one war, this country's troops coined the term "Molotov cocktail" and used cross-country skis to fight a larger enemy force. This country used the Mannerheim line during that war, which was followed by the Continuation War. This country ceded Karelia after losing the Winter War to the Soviets. For 10 points, name this country where the Helsinki Accords were signed.

fields.content: The name "Suomi" in this country possibly originates from the Proto-Baltic word "*źemē", meaning "land". It was largely agrarian until the 1950s, and when baby-boomers entered the workforce, many emigrated to industrialized Sweden. Economists credit product market reforms for its growth. Ranked 17th most competitive by the 2007 IMD World Competitiveness Yearbook, its Constitution defines its political system. Fly rod enthusiasts here favor Atlantic salmon. For 10 points, name this Nordic country in Northern Europe.

fields.content: This country's national epic, the Kalevala, was compiled by Elias Lönnrot from folk poetry collected in the Karelia region. The composer Jean Sibelius, known for his symphonic poem Finlandia, was born in this country. This country's capital is home to the Temppeliaukio Church, also known as the Rock Church, which is carved into solid rock. This country, known for its thousands of lakes and islands, is also home to the northern region of Lapland. For 10 points, name this Nordic country with its capital at Helsinki.

fields.content: The Voronoi diagram of the carbon atoms in diamond consists of truncated versions of the "Triakis" kind of this shape. Adding a vertex that is equidistant to the vertices that comprises this shape creates the pentachoron, since five examples of this shape make up a five-cell. The area of the faces that comprise this shape is the subject of De Gua's theorem. Tartaglia's formula gives the volume of this shape in terms of its dihedral angles. The first four numbers that define this shape's figurate sequence are "1, 4, 10, 20." The Schläfli symbol of this shape is 3 comma 3. The central angle between two of this shape's vertices is approximately 109 degrees. Of the Platonic solids, it is the only self-dual one since at every vertex, three triangles meet. For 10 points, name this regular polyhedron with six edges and four faces.

For 10 points, name this regular polyhedron with six edges and four faces.

fields.content: Stanley Kubrick once scrapped the idea of using a certain geometric shape in his film due to its unfamiliarity to the general public. This shape, often seen at airfields, is mounted on a rotating pivot and always points into the wind. Two of these shapes can form a compound known as the stella octangula. In geometry, the boundary line of the midpoint square intersection traverses every face of this shape. An octahedron can be divided into four identical ones of these shapes. The law of cosines for this shape relates the areas of the faces to the dihedral angles about a vertex. Its skeleton forms a graph with 4 vertices and 6 edges. In a specific case, this shape has an edge length of 2. A condition on 12 angles is necessary and sufficient for them to be the 12 angles of this shape. For 10 points, name this three-dimensional shape with four triangular faces.

This shape is the simplest of the five Platonic solids and has the smallest possible number of faces for a convex polyhedron. This shape's faces are all congruent equilateral triangles, and it has four vertices and six edges. For 10 points, name this three-dimensional shape, a pyramid with a triangular base.

fields.content: In this novel, some office workers can't stop singing after they are hypnotized by a pince-nez-wearing "choirmaster." A subplot of this novel ends with a headache-stricken man revealing to Levi that he had stabbed a traitorous character. In this novel, a servant turns her neighbor into a pig after putting on some magical cream, then flies to Apartment No. 50 for a party on Walpurgis Night. In this novel's first chapter, a streetcar decapitates a chairman of MASSOLIT named Berlioz. In this novel, the pistol-toting cat Behemoth is part of the retinue of Professor Woland, who restores a manuscript about Pontius Pilate written by the first title character. For 10 points, name this novel in which the devil visits Moscow, a work titled for an author and his lover by Mikhail Bulgakov.

fields.content: Professor Jeffrey Grossman of the University of Virginia lauds the Karpelson translation of a novel in his "Faust" courses for its idiomatic accuracy. This novel, influenced by Goethe's "Faust", delves into themes of cowardice, trust, and redemption. It features the Jerusalem of Pontius Pilate, as depicted by Woland and echoed in the Master's novel. Ivan's failed attempt to expose a "gang" lands him in an asylum. The novel's text, including omitted parts, was distributed by hand in a practice known as samizdat. It inspired bands like The Rolling Stones and Patti Smith. A theatrical adaptation involved David Avdysh, Simon Pastukh, and Galina Solovyova. It's commemorated in the only Memorial Museum of Mikhail Bulgakov in Moscow. For 10 points, name this Bulgakov novel.

fields.content: A painting titled for this artist's most famous subject "and Alvaro" depicts a blue door behind some washbuckets. This artist painted a boy in oversized military wear running through a withered winter field. A nude with blonde braids sits next to an open window in this artist's Lovers. This artist's work entered a melancholy period after a train accident killed his father, the creator of notable illustrations of Treasure Island. Recurring subjects for this artist included the Kuerner family of Chadds Ford and his neighbor Helga Testorf. fields.content: This artist's father, during his teenage years, provided his only art lessons. He mastered figure study and watercolor under his father's guidance, and his brother-in-law Peter Hurd taught him egg tempera. He sought a spiritual understanding of the land and sea, based on history and unspoken emotion. His second child, Carolyn, also became a painter. His wife, Betsy, influenced him as much as his father did. He disdained creating art for "effect," and often noted, "I paint my life." For 10 points, name this American realist painter, known for "Christina's World."

fields.content: This artist's early work, "Public Sale," depicts a crowd gathered around a red house, which is a recurring motif in his later works. He often used a technique called "dry brush" in his paintings, which is evident in a work that shows a woman lying in a field near a house, looking at a barn. This artist's most famous work was criticized for its perceived voyeurism and was inspired by his neighbor, Anna Christina Olson. fields.content: Alexander Johnston noted that this body's power came from appointments by popular conventions and state assemblies. Revolutionary Georgians decided to send delegates to this body in 1775. It created the Continental Army and appointed George Washington as its general. John Adams, a member of this body, led the Board of War and Ordnance and urged it to form foreign alliances and a confederation plan. Despite its decisions, like defying the British Navigation Acts, states often ignored this body. Richard Henry Lee presented a resolution declaring independence before this body in 1776. For 10 points, name this legislative body that governed during the Revolutionary War.
clue_list: Alexander Johnston noted that this body's power came from appointments by popular conventions and state assemblies.
Revolutionary Georgians decided to send delegates to this body in 1775.
It created the Continental Army and appointed George Washington as its general.
John Adams, a member of this body, led the Board of War and Ordnance and urged it to form foreign alliances and a confederation plan.
Despite its decisions, like defying the British Navigation Acts, states often ignored this body.
Richard Henry Lee presented a resolution declaring independence before this body in 1776.
For 10 points, name this legislative body that governed during the Revolutionary War.

fields.content: This body was presided over by a man who later became the first governor of Pennsylvania, John Hancock. It appointed a committee of five, including Benjamin Franklin and Thomas Jefferson, to draft a document that was adopted on July 4, 1776. This body also appointed George Washington as the commander-in-chief of the Continental Army. For 10 points, name this legislative body that governed the United States during the American Revolution and adopted the Declaration of Independence.

For 10 points, name this legislative body that governed the United States during the American Revolution and adopted the Declaration of Independence.

fields.content: A savanna between this country's western border and the Rupununi River is said to be the former site of Lake Parime and El Dorado. This present-day country is where the One-Cent Magenta stamp, which is now valued at nearly 9.5 million dollars, was issued. The sugar-producing region of Demerara is one of this country's three original counties. An airstrip in this country's city of Port Kaituma was where the Red Brigade assassinated Congressman Leo Ryan. A mass-suicide by cyanide-laced Flavor Aid brought an end to a Peoples Temple commune in this country nicknamed "Jonestown." This country's eastern neighbor is a former Dutch colony named Suriname. For 10 points, name this country whose capital is Georgetown and which is the only former British colony in South America.

fields.content: This country, first in the Caribbean to sign the 1977 World Heritage treaty, preceded Antigua, Belize, Grenada, Jamaica, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, and Trinidad and Tobago. It nominated Kaieteur National Park, including Kaieteur Falls, as its first World Heritage Site. The British, in 1840, included the entire Cuyuni River basin in their survey of this former colony. Its two main political parties, organized along ethnic lines, often clash over resources. Its name originates from "Guiana", a region that included Suriname, French Guiana, and parts of Colombia, Venezuela, and Brazil. Many of its industries have significant foreign investment. For 10 points, name this South American country once known as British Guiana.

fields.content: In a Yue (you-EH) Minjun parody of this painting, maniacally laughing men in white tshirts and blue shorts stand around a rock. A statue of the dead Hector on a Roman sarcophagus inspired the pose of a pants-less man wearing one blue sock in the bottom left of this painting. This painting of a "modern subject" features an imaginary row of houses in front of a cathedral on its right. This painting likely inspired the character of Gavroche with a boy in a velvet hat who carries two pistols. On the left of this painting, a dandy in a top-hat holds a rifle next to a youth grabbing a stone. The title woman of this painting wears a Phrygian cap and carries the tricolor flag. For 10 points, name this painting which depicts the July Revolution of 1830, by Eugene Delacroix

fields.content: After the June Rebellion of 1832, this artwork was returned to its creator. It was first exhibited at the Grand Palais from November 1974 to February 1975. The artist's statement, "And if I haven’t fought for my country at least I’ll paint for her," reflects its political symbolism. Seen as a republican and anti-monarchist symbol, it drew criticism from royalists. Fintan O'Toole's book "Enough is Enough" references it, replacing the central figure with Kathleen Ni Houlihan. This figure, also a symbol of France known as Marianne, dons a Phrygian cap, a liberty symbol from the 1789–94 French Revolution. For 10 points, name this Eugène Delacroix painting.

For 10 points, name this Eugène Delacroix painting.

fields.content: This painting was created in response to an event that led to the July Monarchy and features a boy brandishing two pistols on the left side. The artist of this painting included a self-portrait as a top-hatted man in the foreground. A wounded man in a blue uniform and a red sash is shown on the right side of this painting, which prominently features a woman holding a flag. That woman, who is bare-breasted, holds the French tricolor in this painting. For 10 points, name this painting by Eugène Delacroix.

fields.content: These species are classified under the E.C. system with four distinct numbers. The burst phase model explains the behavior of these species, which can be tracked with para-nitrophenolate formation. The Briggs-Haldane derivation assumes a low concentration of these species. A mass balance around this species, coupled with the quasi-steady state assumption, is used to define their maximum velocity. An increase in their concentration decreases the y-intercept on a Lineweaver-Burke plot, and their reaction rate is always first-order according to the Michaelis-Menten equation. Induced fit and lock-and-key models describe them. For 10 points, name these proteins whose names usually end in "ase," which catalyze biological reactions of substrates.

fields.content: Certain biological catalysts contain sites to bind and orient catalytic cofactors, bypassing direct involvement of amino acids. They're specific about the substrates they bind and the reactions they catalyze. Denaturation, a process where their structures unfold when heated or exposed to chemical denaturants, often results in activity loss. Coenzymes, small organic molecules, can bind to these catalysts and transport chemical groups between them. Some coenzymes, like riboflavin, thiamine, and folic acid, are vitamins that must be acquired from the diet. These molecules alter the catalysts' conformation or dynamics, affecting the reaction rate at the active site. For 10 points, name this type of protein that accelerates bodily chemical reactions.

For 10 points, name this type of protein that accelerates bodily chemical reactions.

fields.content: This type of protein can be inhibited by molecules that resemble its substrate, a phenomenon known as competitive inhibition. The Michaelis-Menten equation describes the rate of reactions catalyzed by these proteins. These proteins lower the activation energy of reactions, and their active sites bind to specific molecules. For 10 points, name these biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions in the body.

fields.content: A member of this organization was acquitted in the Supreme Court Case establishing the standard of "imminent lawless action" for restricting free speech, Brandenburg v. Ohio. This organization lost credibility after its leader D.C. Stephenson was convicted for the abduction, rape, and murder of a young woman. This organization was restarted after Mary Phagan was supposedly murdered by Jewish factory manager Leo Frank, after which it peaked at 5 million members in the 1920s. In 1963, members of this organization killed four girls by bombing the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham. D.W. Griffith glamorized this organization in his film Birth of a Nation. For 10 points, name this white supremacist organization whose members are known for wearing white hoods.

fields.content: Historians have unearthed membership lists and minutes from local meetings of this group, revealing its widespread presence. In May 1924, Notre Dame students blocked its regional meeting and stole some regalia. This organization, revived by William Joseph Simmons in 1915, is known for coining words beginning with "Kl". Threats of reprisals were made against its members to stop their violent acts against Unionists and black institutions. Despite its violence, it used religious symbols in rituals and honored Bibles and ministers. The 1871 Civil Rights Act, enabling the suspension of "habeas corpus," was a significant measure against it. For 10 points, name this white supremacist group known for its white robes and hoods.

fields.content: This organization was revived by William J. Simmons atop Stone Mountain in 1915, inspired by the film The Birth of a Nation. A member of this group, Byron De La Beckwith, was convicted in 1994 for the 1963 murder of civil rights activist Medgar Evers. This group's second wave in the 1920s was marked by its opposition to Catholics, Jews, and immigrants, in addition to African Americans. fields.content: In his study Seeds in the Heart, Donald Keene suggests that a chapter of this work was ordered destroyed since it told its readers to "flee the world." A poem called "Song of Unending Sorrow" is referred to repeatedly by this book, whose chapter "The Mayfly" describes the third daughter of the Eighth Prince becoming a nun after she decides not to throw herself into a river. This book's protagonist is caught sleeping with "The Lady of the Misty Moon" while in the house of the Minister to the Left, and that protagonist is implied to have died during a blank chapter called "Vanished into the Clouds." This novel's title character is called "Shining" and is unfaithful to his wife Lady Aoi. For 10 points, name this novel about Heian court life by Lady Murasaki.

fields.content: A six-headed creature in this myth system arose when the legs of a sleeping giant mated with each other. The first clouds in this myth system were formed by taking the brains of a creature sometimes called Blainn and throwing them into the sky. A giant in this myth system is nourished by four rivers of milk produced by an animal that licked salty stones to create the first god. The first giant in this myth system was created in a gap between the land of fire and the land of ice. The creation of this myth system's first man and woman, Ask and Embla, is described in the Gylfaginning, which also describes a cow named Audhumla and a giant named Ymir. For 10 points, name this system of myths featuring gods called the Vanir and Aesir.

fields.content: In this belief system, the world is birthed from Ymir's flesh and the first humans are Ask and Embla. Its main source, the "Poetic Edda," is mostly poems with some prose, using fewer kennings. A key figure is a feather-cloaked woman practicing seiðr. Odin, another central figure, self-sacrifices on Yggdrasil to learn the runic alphabet, closely associating him with death, wisdom, and poetry. Often depicted as one-eyed and raven-flanked, Odin seeks knowledge across worlds. Runic inscriptions on the Rök Runestone and Kvinneby amulet reference this system's figures and events. For 10 points, name this ancient Scandinavian religion.

A figure in this belief system is destined to be killed by Vidar at Ragnarok after it kills Odin. fields.content: A leader of this country used the slogan "Seek ye first the political kingdom" after being freed from prison by Charles Arden-Clarke. Conservative advocates for this country's independence called for "Independence in the Shortest Possible Time," in contrast with the slogan "Independence Now" used by the Convention People's Party. While visiting China in 1966, the first leader of this country was overthrown by Joseph Ankrah. That leader used revenue from this country's cocoa exports to fund the hydroelectric Akosombo Dam. This country was ruled by Pan-Africanism advocate Kwame Nkrumah, and it was named for a medieval trading empire centered on Kumbi Saleh. For 10 points, name this West African country, formerly called the Gold Coast, whose capital is Accra.

Tourists are drawn to its tropical climate, exotic waterfalls like Kintampo and Wli, and Lake Volta, the world's largest man-made lake. It has numerous accredited private universities, including Lancaster University. Asante Kotoko SC, a club from this country, was named the African club of the 20th century. Its flag's symbols and colours hold significant meanings. Unlike South Africa, this Group of 24 member is not a newly industrialised country. For 10 points, name this Sub-Saharan African nation.

fields.content: This composer included an Air marked "Andante religioso" in the fourth movement of a suite imitating Baroque music, which he later arranged for string orchestra. He wrote a piano collection whose final movement, "Remembrances," is a tweaked version of the opening "Arietta." This composer was influenced by Robert Schumann to write a piano concerto that begins with a solo timpani roll crescendoing into a loud A minor chord played by the soloist. This composer of Lyric Pieces and the Holberg Suite used a songlike flute solo to depict the sunrise in the "Morning Mood" movement of a suite that later portrays its protagonist being chased by trolls in the title "Hall of the Mountain King." For 10 points, name this composer of the Peer Gynt Suite.

fields.content: Born in Bergen, Norway in 1843, this composer was raised in a musical environment and is known for his nationalistic and cosmopolitan orientation. Despite his Norwegian roots, he traveled extensively across Europe, believing his music reflected both Norwegian rural life and European culture. In 1899, he protested the Dreyfus Affair by cancelling his French concerts, leading to hate mail. His compositions often incorporated lyrics by poets like Heinrich Heine, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, and Rudyard Kipling. For 10 points, name this composer of the "Peer Gynt" suites.

fields.content: In a story in this language, a philosopher who studies Spinoza in an attic on Market Street is nursed back to health by Old Dobbe. In a story in this language, the protagonist is told that there is no God but only a "thick mire" by the "Spirit of Evil." An author used this language to write about a man who "strikes it rich" when he receives a cow from two women whom he finds lost in the woods. In a story in this language, a baker's dying wife Elka reveals that her six children aren't his, prompting him to urinate in his bread dough. This language was used to write "Gimpel the Fool," as well as stories about Tevye the Milkman. For 10 points, name this language used by Isaac Bashevis Singer and Sholem Aleichem, as well as other Ashkenazi Jewish writers.

fields.content: A dialect of this language spoken in Lithuania is known as Litvish. This language's alphabet is nearly identical to that of Hebrew, but it also includes several unique letters such as the double-vav and the double-yud. This language was the primary language of Ashkenazi Jews, and it was heavily influenced by German, Slavic languages, and Hebrew. fields.content: It's not a chemical reaction, but the temperature dependence of this process in a solid can be modeled using the Eyring equation and transition state theory. Two particles with opposite charges can undergo this process in an "ambipolar" fashion. Either ion implantation or this process are the main methods used in industry to dope semiconductors. The heat equation is sometimes named for this process, since convection and this process are governed by the same mathematical laws. The flux of this phenomenon is equal to minus a namesake coefficient times the gradient of concentration according to Fick's Law. For 10 points, osmosis is an example of what form of passive mass transport, in which atoms move from high to low concentration?

fields.content: The Chapman and Cowling book notes a "T" dependence for rigid spheres, similar to the mean free path theory, but with a different exponent for power repulsion laws. This process also applies to gases in porous media, formalized in an equation akin to Darcy's law, involving permeability, viscosity, and pressure. The so-called activity is represented by formula_51, while Fick's law describes the driving force as the antigradient of concentration, or formula_22. The diffusing quantity, formula_2, could be particles, mass, energy, charge, or another scalar extensive quantity. fields.content: The shmura type of this item is produced under special supervision. The explanation for this item's purpose is given by the declaration Ha Lachma Anya. Many Hasidim abstain from the gebrochts type of this item, which has absorbed liquid. Wet precursors of this product may only be left out for 18 minutes. Fruit juice is often used in place of water to produce the "egg" type of this item, which may not actually use eggs. A half-piece of this item that is set aside for later is known as an afikoman. It's not wine, but Manischewitz (man-uh-SHEV-its) popularized the mass production of this food, which commemorates the fact that during the Exodus, the Jews had to flee Egypt before their bread could rise. For 10 points, name this unleavened flatbread eaten during Passover.

fields.content: A certain view suggests flour mixed with liquids other than water, such as fruit juice or milk, doesn't need the same care to prevent fermentation. This perspective is relevant to Syrian Christians in Kerala, who celebrate Pesaha with this item, and to the Catholic Church, which uses similar unleavened bread for the Eucharist. This item, comparable to rye crispbread with 111 calories per ounce, is often served in soup as balls or farfel. The Torah mentions it in relation to The Exodus from Egypt, imbuing it with symbolism. It represents both redemption and freedom, and is also known as "lechem oni", or "poor man's bread". For 10 points, name this unleavened bread eaten during Passover.

fields.content: This work's composer later reused the lyrics that begin its final chorus "Wer ein holdes Weib errungen" for one of his symphonies. Robert Schumann took his "passionate" pseudonym from this opera's male lead. Its Act 1 Finale opens with a crowd joyfully singing "O Welche Lust." At the beginning of its second and final act, its male lead sings "God! How dark it is here" before remembering "Spring days of life" in the aria "In des Lebens Frühlingstagen." This opera's last scene is often preceded by the last of three overtures named for the female lead. This opera ends as Don Pizarro is dragged off to prison, and a crowd celebrates how Florestan was saved from jail by Leonore cross-dressing as the title boy. For 10 points, name this only opera by Ludwig van Beethoven.

fields.content: Beethoven's only opera, catalogued as Opus 72, premiered in 1805 with a libretto adapted by Joseph Sonnleithner. Despite his increasing deafness, Beethoven led the premiere, assisted by Michael Umlauf. The composer later shortened this work for a 1808 Prague performance, creating "Leonore No. 1". Beethoven once wrote to Treitschke that this opera would earn him a "martyr's crown". The plot includes Rocco revealing Pizarro's murder scheme, leading to Pizarro's imprisonment. A character sings of his faith in God and envisions his wife Leonore rescuing him, uttering "Gott! Helft den Armen!" This phrase serves as a musical reprise of the rescue scene. Intriguingly, the fall of the Berlin Wall occurred four weeks after a performance of this opera. For 10 points, name this opera whose title means "Faithful".

fields.content: Laguerre's method for finding these quantities is one of many algorithms that "polishes" them by repeatedly "deflating" a function. An algorithm that finds these quantities successively computes "x sub n" by subtracting the expression "f of x sub 0 divided by f prime of x sub 0" from "x sub n minus 1." An upper bound on the number of these quantities can be found with Descartes' Rule of Signs. There is no general method for finding these quantities for expressions higher than the fourth degree according to the AbelRuffini theorem. These quantities, which can be found using the Newton-Raphson method, are defined as inputs to a function such that it outputs zero. For 10 points, name these quantities that are given by the quadratic formula for trinomials.

fields.content: The cork cambium forms the periderm, consisting of protective cork cells with suberin. This structure's early growth is influenced by hormones and pathways, with the apical meristem near the tip playing a key role. Its depth can be limited by rock, compacted soil, or anaerobic conditions. As it matures, its cells differentiate into specialized tissues. Native Americans utilized the flexible ones of white spruce for basketry. Its primary tissues first undergo elongation, pushing its tip forward in the growing medium. For 10 points, name this plant part that absorbs water and nutrients from the soil.

fields.content: The speaker of this poem compares its setting to a "savage place" haunted by a "woman wailing for her demon-lover," and it analogizes some huge flying rock fragments to "chaffy grain beneath the thresher's flail." This poem's speaker imagines himself with "flashing eyes" and "floating hair" as a consequence of his eating honeydew and drinking "the milk of Paradise." This poem's final section describes its speaker's vision of an Abyssinian maid playing on a dulcimer and singing of Mount Abora, and it begins with a description of a site where "Alph, the sacred river ran, through caverns measureless to man." A "stately-pleasure dome" is decreed in Xanadu in, for 10 points, what poem by Samuel Taylor Coleridge named for a Mongol ruler?

A critic noted, "there are no other 'Ancient Mariners' or these, nor are there likely to be," but lamented that such views lead "away" from the poem. fields.content: This book recounts the story of Eutychus, a man in Troas who falls from a window and is immediately revived. In this book, a Pharisee named Gamaliel advises a council to leave some other men alone, and an Ethiopian eunuch converts to Christianity. At the opening of this book, lots are drawn and Matthias is chosen to replace a man who had died. Philip meets the Samaritan sorcerer Simon Magus in this book, which also chronicles the stoning of Stephen, the first martyr. Ananias restored the life of Saul of Damascus in this book, which described how he converted to Christianity and became Paul the Apostle. For 10 points, Luke is said to have written what fifth book of the New Testament named for the deeds of Jesus's disciples?

fields.content: Luke's work, which explores more than just "edification," or the empirical demonstration of virtue's superiority over vice, contains parallels to the Gospel of Luke, such as the presentation of Jesus in the Temple and his forty days of testing. This work also brings the message to the Samaritans and Gentiles. Its title, "Praxeis Apostolon," was first coined by Irenaeus in the late 2nd century. It narrates the establishment of the Gentile church in Antioch, where followers of Christ were first called Christians, and questions a Christian's relationship with the Roman Empire. This book describes the conversion of a man on the road to Damascus, who is blinded by a light from heaven and hears the voice of Jesus. fields.content: Solutions of this ion turn green after adding ammonium heptamolybdate. During Maxam-Gilbert sequencing, this ion is radioactively labeled and incorporated into cells. Two of these ions linked together are given the prefix "pyro." Salts of this anion and chloride compose a common biological buffer that's isotonic to blood. This fully deprotonated molecule has three pKa values at 2.1, 7.2, and 12.7. This ion is called "inorganic" when it's a monomer. The first step of glycolysis attaches this tetrahedral ion to glucose through the enzyme glucokinase. It comprises the polar head groups in the cell membrane, and it links sugars in the backbone of DNA. For 10 points, name this ion with a negative-three charge and four oxygen atoms bonded to a central phosphorus.

fields.content: Nauru and Banaba Island were once rich in a compound that forms polymeric ions like pyrophosphate. Related compounds, such as substituted phosphines, lack natural counterparts but are useful in organic chemistry. Salts of this compound, including NaHPO4 and Na2HPO4, are used in buffer solutions at cell pHs. The acid form of this compound is in equilibrium with its conjugate base, defined by pKa, due to differing successive pKa values. The hydrogen and dihydrogen forms of this compound are more soluble than the compound itself, though many forms are insoluble in water at standard conditions. This compound is also significant in southeast US tobacco farming. For 10 points, name this key component of fertilizers and DNA.

fields.content: This figure shares his name with a historian from Halicarnassus whose Romaike Archaeologica is a source of Etruscan mythology. The Rhodope Mountains were sacred to this figure, who was worshiped in an ancient temple now found at Baalbek. This god's attributes include the kantharos, a two-handled cup, as well a bassaris fox skin, which is why his followers are sometimes called bassarids. Dithyrambs were songs that honored this god, whose followers carried a pinecone-topped staff called the thyrsus. This god was born after his mother foolishly asked to see Zeus in all of his glory; after the resulting death of Semele, he was stitched into Zeus's thigh and reborn. Liber and Bacchus are alternate names of, for 10 points, what Greek god of revelry and wine?

fields.content: This deity, often considered foreign in Greek mythology, is linked to Mount Nysa, set far to the east or south. Friedrich Hölderlin drew parallels between this figure and Christ, particularly in "Brod und Wein" and "Der Einzige". This god was a pupil of the centaur Chiron. Theories comparing this deity and Christ were popular in the 19th century. In a myth, Pentheus hides in a tree hoping to witness this god's rites. Aristophanes' "The Frogs" features a third descent by this deity to Hades. He's also called Euius in Euripides' "The Bacchae". For 10 points, name this Greek god of wine.

A group of women who worshipped this deity were driven mad and killed Orpheus, according to one myth. fields.content: In 2014, a certain novel was adapted for the Utah Shakespeare Festival by Joseph Hanreddy and J.R. Sullivan. The story begins with Mrs Dashwood moving her family to Devonshire's Barton Cottage, near her cousin, Sir John Middleton. Edward Ferrars visits this location but appears unhappy. The novel's title is represented by Elinor, embodying "sense", and Marianne, embodying "sensibility". Marianne, characterized by her intelligence and capacity to love deeply, is assisted by John Willoughby after an accident. However, Austen biographer Claire Tomalin suggests that the novel's approach "wobbles", as Austen became uncertain about whether sense or sensibility should prevail. For 10 points, name this Jane Austen novel.

Her career was marked by numerous honors, and her personal life included a 1965 marriage to Blakely and Hardiman.
For 10 points, name this Pulitzer Prize-winning poet of "Annie Allen".

fields.content: This author wrote a poem in which the speaker claims "We Jazz June. We / Die soon," after describing a group of pool players who are "real cool." This author of "We Real Cool" also wrote a novel about the life of a black girl named Maud Martha. fields.content: People of this type were led by a drummer boy named Hans Bohm in a bonfire of vanities. Several movements of these people used a flag depicting the "bound shoe." A call for "everyone who can [to] smite, slay, and stab" these people was issued during a war in which they were briefly led by a knight with an iron prosthetic hand. The abolition of the death tax was demanded in the Twelve Articles issued by these people. Before the Battle of Frankenhausen, a movement of these people in Swabia was led by Thomas Muntzer. A revolt of these people was condemned in a pamphlet about "murderous and thieving hordes" by Martin Luther. For 10 points, name this class of agricultural laborers who name a 15th-century war in Germany.

fields.content: In 1525, 25 villages under Memmingen rebelled, demanding economic and political improvements. A key figure helped peasants articulate grievances in the Klettgau area. These grievances became the Twelve Articles, printed 25,000 times and spread across Germany, showing how modernization aided the rebels. The rebels stormed the castle of the Counts of Schwarzburg. Concurrently, Charles V of Spain was the Holy Roman Emperor. According to Friedrich Engels, the progress of printing and commerce, along with renaissance humanism, raised literacy rates. The aristocratic clergy, opposing all change, did not align with Martin Luther. Later, East German historians researched this event to support the Marxist viewpoint. For 10 points, name this early 16th-century uprising.

Concurrently, Charles V of Spain was the Holy Roman Emperor.

Later, East German historians researched this event to support the Marxist viewpoint.
For 10 points, name this early 16th-century uprising.

fields.content: A leader of this conflict wrote a tract titled "The Twelve Articles," which was one of the first documents to demand religious freedom and political rights in Europe. This conflict was sparked by the imposition of a new tithe to fund a war against the Ottoman Empire. Martin Luther initially sympathized with the rebels in this conflict but later condemned them in his pamphlet "Against the Murderous, Thieving Hordes of Peasants." This conflict, which took place from 1524 to 1525, was one of the largest popular uprisings in Europe until the French Revolution. For 10 points, name this revolt that took place in the Holy Roman Empire.

fields.content: Binary space partitioning is often done using the "oct-" variant of these entities. Hidden surface removal can often be done with the "quad-" variant of them. The order of elements varies when performing a depth-first traversal of these things depending on whether the traversal is pre-order, post-order or in-order. They are isomorphic to directed acyclic graphs. Georgy Adelson-Velsky and Evgenii Landis developed the selfbalancing "AVL" variant of these structures, which use "rotations" when a new element is added to one of them. Two "children" can be found at the bottom of every level in the "complete binary" type of these structures. For 10 points, name these data structures which begin with a root node, and whose lowest level nodes are called leaves.

fields.content: A node, which may contain a value or represent a separate data structure, is a key component of this concept. Each node has zero or more child nodes, and the highest node is called the root. Standard drawings of this structure place the root at the top and nodes at a given distance from the root on a horizontal line. To allow finiteness, the list of children can be empty, or the structure itself can be empty with a fixed-size list of children. As an abstract data type, it's defined using the abstract forest type, with "nil" and "node" constructors. When embedded in the plane, it's unique up to ambient isotopy. For 10 points, name this data structure used in computer science.

fields.content: A type of this data structure, named for Rudolf Bayer and Edward M. McCreight, maintains balance by performing rotations and has a maximum height of log base 2 of n. Another type of this data structure, named for Adelson, Velski, and Landis, also self-balances and is often used to implement associative arrays. fields.content: The "Dutch Process" for preparing a pigment of this color involved heaping buckets of animal manure around clay pots full of metal and acetic acid; that pigment of this color was used to make Venetian Ceruse, a cosmetic that often gave women lead poisoning. Beeswax was used in a Jasper Johns painting using this color only to depict the U.S. flag. Because of its large collection of Bauhaus buildings, part of Tel Aviv is nicknamed the "city" of this color. Joanna Hiffernan appeared in a dress of this color in three "symphonies" created by James Whistler. James Hoban designed a building named after this color whose address is 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. Neoclassical buildings and sculptures made use of, for 10 points, what color that describes the "House" of the American President?

fields.content: In the Renaissance, Leon Battista Alberti urged artists to use a certain color to brighten their work and add "hilaritas". In Shinto, a "niwa" of this color gravel marks a sacred place. The Romans had two words for it: "albus", a plain version, and "candidus", a brighter one. Non-European languages also have diverse terms for this color. During Dhu al-Hijjah in the Islamic calendar, an Ihram of this color is worn. John the Baptist symbolically linked Christ to this color as the lamb of God. 19th-century painter James McNeill Whistler used it to create moods in his paintings. For 10 points, name this color often associated with purity and innocence.

fields.content: This color is associated with a group of artists who were named after a 1913 exhibition at the 69th Regiment Armory. A flag of this color is internationally recognized as a symbol of surrender. For 10 points, name this color that, along with blue and red, is one of the three colors on the American flag.

fields.content: In this work's preface, a man purchases a writing desk at a second-hand store and hacks it open to find two manuscripts. A person in this work asks "Who deserves to be the unhappiest?" in a section addressed to the Symparanekromenoi (SIM-pah-rah-neh-KROmeh-noi), a club that writes posthumous papers. It asks "What is a poet?" in its group of aphorisms, Diapsalmata. The narrator of one section of this book advocates staving off boredom with "crop rotation." Stages on Life's Way is a follow-up to this book, in whose second section Judge Vilhelm tries to convince "A" of the validity of marriage. The aesthetic life view is contrasted with the ethical and religious in this 1834 work, which is attributed to Victor Eremita. For 10 points, name this two-volume book by Søren Kierkegaard.

fields.content: While in Germany, Søren Kierkegaard worked on a manuscript, attended operas and plays, and perfected his German. This work, like Faustus, asks "Who made the world?" and explores the inner life of historical figures. Its second part, "Discourse on Life as a Duty," ends with the moral philosopher in despair. The author revisits the theme of inner and outer aspects of tragedy and introduces the idea that pleasure can be tempered with ethics, a theme further developed in "Fear and Trembling." The exploration of sorrow and pain is also a significant aspect of this work. For 10 points, name this philosophical work by Kierkegaard that presents the aesthetic and ethical ways of life as a choice.

fields.content: A character in this work, named Victor Eremita, discovers an antique secretary desk containing two sets of papers, each representing a different life view. This work introduces the concept of "aesthetic" and "ethical" stages of life, and it is divided into two parts, the first of which includes the "Diary of a Seducer" and the second of which contains a sermon-like discourse on the story of Abraham and Isaac. This work, which is often considered the first major text of existentialism, was published under the pseudonym Victor Eremita. For 10 points, name this philosophical work by Søren Kierkegaard.

fields.content: Aciclovir is built from a hydroxymethyl group bound to this compound. Cisplatin prevents a "suicide enzyme" methyltransferase from binding this compound. It can be formed by reductive amination of xanthine. This compound's namesake exchange factors, which oppose GAPs, add a phosphate group to a di-phosphorylated derivative of this compound. The 5-prime cap is formed from a ribosylated, methylated form of this compound. This compound, which has an imidazole ring, donates two hydrogen bonds and accepts one. A class of proteins named for this compound act as molecular switches after receiving signals from GPCRs. This purine is rich in very stable DNA sequences. For 10 points, name this nitrogenous base that pairs with cytosine.

fields.content: A 2011 report suggested that this molecule, a building block of DNA and RNA, may have formed in outer space. Present in both DNA and RNA, it binds to cytosine through three hydrogen bonds. It has two tautomeric forms and can be converted from uric acid, as Fischer showed between 1882 and 1906. Spiders and scorpions convert ammonia to this molecule, which can be hydrolyzed with strong acid to glycine, ammonia, carbon dioxide, and carbon monoxide. Found in the skin of many fish, its crystals produce a pearly luster due to their high index of refraction. For 10 points, name this purine base found in sturgeon skin and known for its role in DNA and RNA.

fields.content: This molecule's structure was first determined by the chemist Robert Burns Woodward. It is one of the five nucleobases in the nucleic acids, two of which are purines, and it is the only one that functions as a protein kinase inhibitor. This molecule pairs with a pyrimidine in DNA through three hydrogen bonds, more than any other base pair, which contributes to the stability of the DNA structure. fields.content: The protagonist of this novel leaves a group after hypnotizing its leader, who had taught him exercises such as standing in a thorn bush without bleeding. After having a dream in which he throws away a dead songbird, the protagonist of this novel leaves his home and contemplates killing himself by jumping from a coconut tree. A spoiled boy in this novel steals a boat from his father, with whom he is forced to live with after his mother is killed by a snake-bite. The title character of this novel abandons his work as a merchant and his relationship with the courtesan Kamala to work as a ferryman with Vasudeva. As a young man, this novel's protagonist hears the Buddha speak with his friend Govinda. For 10 points, name this novel set in India by Herman Hesse.

fields.content: This primary figure in a certain religion was born a Kshatriya, son of Śuddhodana, chief of the Shakya clan, in Kapilavastu, later annexed by the Kingdom of Kosala. Despite no extant human depictions until the 1st century CE, scriptures attribute detailed physical descriptions to him, found in the Digha Nikaya. He was addressed by titles such as Buddha, Shākyamuni, and Shākyasimha, but post-parinirvana, he was known as Arihant, Bhagavā, and most popularly, Tathāgata. The Burmese Buddhist tradition records his death on 13 May 544 BCE. For 10 points, name this founder of Buddhism.

fields.content: This figure's first sermon, the Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta, was delivered in a deer park near Varanasi, where he set in motion the "Wheel of Dhamma." This figure is said to have defeated the demon Mara while meditating under a Bodhi tree, achieving a state of perfect understanding. This figure's teachings form the basis of the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path. Born as Siddhartha Gautama in Lumbini, he is the founder of a major world religion. fields.content: A piece of Canada Balsam is placed in between two specimens of this mineral to create the Nicol Prism. Ancient ooids (oh-oy-ds) are often composed from the "seas" of this substance that characterize the Paleozoic and the early Mesozoic Eras. The rock onyx is often confused for the "banded" form of this mineral found in Mexican mines. The highly unstable polymorph vaterite is converted to this mineral when it is exposed to water at low temperature. Erasmus Bartholin first observed "double refraction" in a variety of this mineral known as Iceland spar. Aragonite is a polymorph of this mineral which can be found in mineral springs. For 10 points, Limestone is made of what mineral that has a value of "3" on the Mohs scale of hardness, and is composed of calcium carbonate?

fields.content: Amorphous calcium carbonate (ACC) crystallizes into vaterite, a mineral less stable than aragonite, which transforms into another mineral at 380–470°C. This mineral is found in rocks like carbonatites and kimberlites, and filled seas alternating with aragonite seas during the Ordovician and Jurassic. The birefringent effect using this mineral was first described by Rasmus Bartholin in 1669. It has a Mohs hardness of 3, a specific gravity of 2.71, and a vitreous luster in crystallized forms. Like most carbonates, it dissolves in most acids. For 10 points, name this mineral defined as value 3 on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness.

It is known for its double refraction property when viewed through a clear piece of this mineral. fields.content: Because this man once slept with the nymph Melite, Zeus forbade her from sexual relations afterwards. Apollodorus states that this man killed a ruler of Egypt who sacrificed all of his visitors. This slayer of Busiris was once told by Xenoclea that he would be purified of killing Iphitus if he served Queen Omphale. While he traveled with the Argonauts, his companion Hylas was abducted by water nymphs. This man once fought a son of Poseidon whose strength increased as he touched the earth. This man's exploits include wrestling Antaeus and murdering his music teacher Linus. He was forced to serve Eurystheus to perform a group of tasks that involved defeating the Stymphalian Birds and the Nemean Lion. For 10 points, name this Greek hero who performed twelve labors.

fields.content: After killing his tutor Linus with a lyre, this figure was sent to tend cattle by his foster father Amphitryon. Herodotus claimed that 22 Kings of Lydia descended from him and Omphale. Before his death, he threw Lichas into the sea, believing him to be his poisoner. He spared Laomedon's son Podarces, renamed Priam, in exchange for a golden veil. He complied with a request, resulting in multiple pregnancies and sons. Teams worldwide bear his name or symbol. Prometheus predicted his future deeds. Kings of Sparta and Macedon traced their lineage to his sons. He's mentioned in the Hymn to Artemis. For 10 points, name this hero known for twelve labors.

fields.content: This figure was instructed by a centaur named Pholus to use the blood of the Lernaean Hydra to poison his arrows. This figure was forced to serve as a slave to Omphale, the queen of Lydia, as a punishment for killing Iphitus. This figure's wife, Deianira, unwittingly poisoned him by giving him a shirt soaked in the blood of the centaur Nessus. This figure's most famous tasks include cleaning the Augean stables and capturing Cerberus. For 10 points, name this Greek hero who performed twelve labors.

This figure was forced to serve as a slave to Omphale, the queen of Lydia, as a punishment for killing Iphitus.
This figure's wife, Deianira, unwittingly poisoned him by giving him a shirt soaked in the blood of the centaur Nessus.

fields.content: Cardinal Giulio Alberoni's plan to overthrow this non-French monarch was foiled by the wreck of the Duke of Ormond's fleet and by the Battle of Glen Shiel. As a means of allowing his subjects to curry favor, this monarch revived the Order of the Bath. This king's foreign minister Viscount Stanhope helped create the Quadruple Alliance to fight Spain. This monarch was challenged by the "Old Pretender" during the first Jacobite uprising. The South Sea Bubble occurred during the reign of this monarch, who appointed Robert Walpole as prime minister. The Act of Settlement elevated this Elector of Hanover to the throne after the death of Queen Anne. For 10 points, name this man who was crowned King of Britain in 1714 and was followed by three kings who took his name.

fields.content: This figure, the eldest son of Ernest Augustus and Sophia of the Palatinate, was multilingual, speaking German, French, Latin, Italian, and Dutch. In 1717, political upheaval saw Lord Townshend dismissed and Walpole resign, leading to Lord Stanhope and Sunderland's dominance in foreign and domestic affairs respectively. Despite the unsettled Scottish succession, he bypassed fifty-six Catholics to ascend to power. His mother, Sophia, became heiress presumptive to the English throne. His reign ended abruptly when he suffered a stroke in 1727 and died at the Prince-Bishop's palace at Osnabrück. For 10 points, name this first Hanoverian monarch of Britain.

fields.content: A temporary, elevated altar called the vedi bore this substance in homa rituals. A god of this substance rides in a chariot pulled by either two parrots, a goat, or a ram, and is the subject of the first hymn of the Rig Veda. Trays bearing this substance are rotated in a circle during aarti, and yajna rituals are performed using it. During the saptapadi ritual at Hindu weddings, the bride and groom take seven steps around this substance together. An appalled Queen Victoria issued a ban on a practice involving this substance in 1861. Offerings of ghee are lapped up by seven tongues of this substance belonging to the Vedic god Agni, its personification. For 10 points, name this substance which consumed women who performed sati by jumping on a funeral pyre.

fields.content: The California Contractors State License Board lacks a classification for restoration related to this phenomenon. To enhance passive protection, building materials are tested for resistance to this phenomenon. Its control marked a significant shift in early human habits. In zero gravity, this phenomenon becomes spherical and more efficient. It's used in power stations to heat water, generating steam that drives turbines. Power plants using fossil fuels, which are linked to this phenomenon, supply nearly 80% of the world's electricity. Homer described Greek soldiers using it to destroy Troy. Surfaces above a certain temperature emit light, a phenomenon associated with this element. For 10 points, name this element essential for combustion.

In a mythological context, a figure who stole this phenomenon from the gods and gave it to humanity was punished by being chained to a rock where an eagle ate his liver every day. fields.content: This leader developed the pseudo-scientific Sun Language Theory, which conveniently proposed that an ancestor of his country's language was actually the origin of all the world's languages. This man's country was allowed to regulate passage on a key body of water by the Montreux Convention. The Great Fire of Smyrna began after his troops recaptured the city, and he expelled over one million ethnic Greeks from his country the following year. As president, he introduced a new Latin alphabet for his country's language and promoted the Six Arrows ideology, which enforced strict separation of church and state and banned the wearing of the fez. In 1920, he helped establish a new capital at Ankara. For 10 points, name this founder and first president of modern Turkey.

He created a banner symbolizing the shift from Ottoman to republican rule. A 1926 assassination plot against him was discovered in İzmir. During his rule, Lord Curzon dismissed the existence of oil as hypothetical, and his era saw a significant reconciliation with Greece. He introduced the Latin alphabet to replace the Ottoman Turkish alphabet and implemented a series of reforms known as the Six Arrows, which included secularism and nationalism. fields.content: This city's name became the nickname of a series of quartets by Georg Philipp Telemann because those quartets became popular here. A treatise that claimed to have found the "fundamental bass" of Western music, the Treatise on Harmony, was published in this city where, in the 1750s, a pamphlet war about the merits of two different countries' styles of music called the "War of the Buffoons" broke out. Mozart's Symphony No. 31 is nicknamed for this city, which titles a symphonic poem that features four taxi horns. A riot broke out at the premiere of The Rite of Spring in this national capital. George Gershwin wrote a tone poem about an "American in" this city. For 10 points, name this European capital whose conservatory taught Claude Debussy.

fields.content: The pathogen that causes this disease secretes the antigens F1 and V and was codiscovered by Kitasato Shibasaburo. This disease's pathogen uses a type III secretion system to deliver its effectors called Yops. It is endemic to prairie dogs in the western US. The two other forms of this disease are septicemic and pneumonic. The bacterium that causes this disease, Yersinia pestis, forms a biofilm in the esophagus of its animal vector. The best known form of this disease gets its name from sufferers' swollen lymph nodes on the armpits or groin, which is typically transmitted by insect bite. For 10 points, name this disease transmitted by the rat flea, which killed a third of Europe during the Middle Ages.

fields.content: Primarily transmitted by infected fleas from small animals, this disease's bacteria aggregate in the flea's gut, causing the flea to regurgitate infected blood into a rodent or human host. Rapid dipstick tests screen for the "Y. pestis" antigen in patients. Medieval doctors attributed it to corrupted air from humid weather, decaying bodies, and poor sanitation. A notable epidemic began with a Mongol attack on the Italian merchants' station in Caffa, Crimea. During outbreaks, visiting infected areas was forbidden, with violators barred from city re-entry. Treated cases have a 1–15% mortality rate, while untreated cases reach 40–60%. For 10 points, name this pandemic also known as the Black Death.

fields.content: This disease is believed to have been the cause of the Plague of Justinian, which devastated the Byzantine Empire in the 6th century. The bacterium that causes this disease is carried by fleas that infest rats, and it can be transmitted to humans through flea bites. The most infamous outbreak of this disease, known as the Black Death, killed an estimated 75-200 million people in the 14th century. Symptoms include fever, weakness, and swollen and painful lymph nodes, also known as "buboes". For 10 points, name this highly infectious and often deadly disease, also known as the Black Plague.

fields.content: In this novel, a sleepwalker carries his wife across a river and lays her in a stone sarcophagus in the ruins of a Cistercian (sis-TUR-shan) abbey. This novel's protagonist describes the "blighted star" they live on to her brother Abraham just before accidentally killing their family horse Prince. At Talbothay's dairy, this novel's protagonist befriends the milkmaids Izz, Retty, and Marian, who all love a man who leaves Wessex to explore farming options in Brazil. After a police chase concludes at Stonehenge, this novel ends with a gentleman farmer and his sister-in-law watching for the black flag that signals the execution of a woman who murders Alec, the father of her illegitimate baby Sorrow. For 10 points, name this Thomas Hardy novel about a woman who marries Angel Clare.

fields.content: Set in Thomas Hardy's fictional Wessex during the 1870s Long Depression, this novel's protagonist faces a dilemma when her lover, Angel, assumes her purity, making her fear revealing her past. Angel introduces her to his parents, who consent to meet her. The couple later finds solace in an empty mansion for five days until a cleaning woman discovers them. After leaving her and journeying to Brazil, Angel becomes so ill he's reduced to a "mere yellow skeleton". For 10 points, name this Hardy novel.

fields.content: The very strong CAG promoter contains the start of a gene encoding this protein in chickens. This 43-kilodalton protein and GAPDH are the most common loading controls for Western blots. This protein is stained red by phalloidin, and is regulated by the Rho GTPase family. Two critical concentrations of this protein determine if it polymerizes at the barbed end, the pointed end, or both. At the cellular leading edge, it forms lamellipodia, and it can also bundle together to make stress fibers. A form this protein labelled F is formed by ATP hydrolysis and makes up a smaller component of the cytoskeleton than microtubules. fields.content: The protagonist of this novel resorts to shooting nine angry challengers with his revolver after his rival strips him of his lasso. The protagonist of this novel repaires a well to cause water to flow again into the Valley of Holiness. The novel's hero's nostalgia for a telephone operator leads him to name his child Hello-Central, and he gets called "The Boss" after using explosives to cause a rival magician's tower to crumble. fields.content: Soldiers who formerly fought for this state resorted to cannibalism when they were lured into a canyon called "the saw" during the "Truceless War." Shortly after forming an alliance with this state, King Syphax was beaten at the Battle of Great Plains. This state's forces employed a turning movement in an ambush that destroyed the legions of Gaius Flaminius. After this state violated the Ebro Treaty, it besieged the town of Saguntum. After this state was victorious at the Battle of Lake Trasimene, Fabius Maximus began employing a delaying strategy against its forces. Years after this empire failed to follow up on its victory at Cannae, Scipio Africanus defeated this state at the Battle of Zama. For 10 points, what empire fought the three Punic wars with Rome?

fields.content: Virgil depicted this city, once home to simple huts, as filled with "marvelous buildings, gateways, cobbled ways" upon Aeneas's arrival. It was located on a 50-meter ridge extending along the seashore, forming a plateau between the Byrsa and the sea. Mago's agricultural advice to landowners was to treat their workers well for 'utilitarian' interests. His writings were likely for the "master of a modest estate." Today, the Lycée Gustave Flaubert stands here. However, this previously disarmed city faced a fatal Roman siege. For 10 points, name this ancient city-state in modern-day Tunisia.

fields.content: The power of this phenomenon for a particular order is optimized in a technique known as "blazing," which generally minimizes its zeroth order form. This phenomenon can be used in an experiment in combination with the Scherrer equation to determine the size of particles of a powder. It is common to measure the thickness of a strand of hair using this phenomenon and Babinet's principle. James Gregory theorized a device consisting of periodic "gratings" which would induce this phenomenon. The formula "two times distance times sine of the scattering angle is equal to n times wavelength" describes this phenomenon; that equation, Bragg's law, describes this phenomenon's use in crystallography. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which a light wave bends around an obstacle.

fields.content: Ocean waves diffract around obstacles, a behavior explained by models like the Kirchhoff-Fresnel diffraction equation and the Fraunhofer and Fresnel approximations. These models consider wave displacement as the sum of secondary waves. The amplitude of a wave from a point source, given by the Helmholtz Equation, is dependent on the effective path length. This principle extends to the entire height of a slit, where the condition for destructive interference is the same as for two narrow slits half the slit's width apart. For 10 points, name this wave phenomenon causing light to bend around corners and spread out after passing through narrow apertures.

fields.content: This phenomenon was first mathematically described by Francesco Maria Grimaldi, who coined its name from the Latin for "to break into pieces." The Huygens-Fresnel principle, which treats every point in a wavefront as a secondary source of spherical wavelets, is often used to explain this phenomenon. The double-slit experiment, which demonstrates the wave-particle duality of light, relies on this phenomenon. For 10 points, name this wave phenomenon that occurs when a wave encounters an obstacle or a slit, causing the wave to bend and spread out.

fields.content: In a piece by this composer, the pianist plays octave tremolos in the right hand to depict the eerie light emitted by skulls. This composer used a scene from Goethe's Faust in which Mephistopheles enters Auerbach's cellar as the basis of his "Song of the Flea." A suite by this composer begins with a piece alternating between 5/4 and 6/4 time, and includes the movements "Con Mortuis in Lingua Mortua" and "The Market at Limoges." After this composer died, Rimsky-Korsakov edited many of his works, including a symphonic poem in which a church bell interrupts a witches' sabbath. He traced his lineage to Rurik, founder of the Russian state. In 1858, he left his commission to study with Balakirev and focus on music. His unfinished opera "Khovanshchina" was completed posthumously by Rimsky-Korsakov and premiered in 1886. Tenor Vladimir Rosing made early recordings of his songs in the 1920s and 1930s. For 10 points, name this Russian composer.

fields.content: In one story, this god granted the left half of his body to his wife, resulting in a combined form called Ardhanarishvara. This god tore off a fingernail to create the wrathful Bhairava, who guards places where the ashes of Shakti are worshiped. The Vedic Rudra is considered a predecessor to this deity, who lives atop Mount Kailasa. This god is often depicted trampling a dwarf representing ignorance in the form of Nataraja, the lord of the dance. His throat turned blue when he swallowed the Halahala poison during the churning of the ocean of milk. His mount is the white bull Nandi, and he had two children, Kartikeya and Ganesha, with his wife Parvati. For 10 points, name this "destroyer" god of the Hindu Trimurti, in which he is joined by Brahma and Vishnu.

fields.content: This deity is part of a practice using icons of five equivalent deities in a quincunx pattern. The persona of this figure as a composite deity is a subject of speculation. Some interpretations suggest this deity's facial features are bovine, possibly a divine buffalo-man. Along with Vishnu, this figure is revered in the "Devi Mahatmya", a text as important as the "Bhagavad Gita". In the "Shiva Sahasranama", this deity's name translates as "(the Supreme Lord of) Time." Texts dedicated to this figure include the "Shiva Sutras" and works by 10th-century scholar Abhinavagupta. This deity is part of the Trimurti in Hinduism, personifying destruction alongside Brahma and Vishnu. For 10 points, name this destroyer or transformer in the Trimurti.

fields.content: In 1991, this country stopped distributing communal plots of lands known as ejidos (ay-HEE-doze) to its peasants. In 1994, this country faced massive capital flight after it suddenly unpegged its currency from the U.S. dollar, during what became known as the "December Mistake." That same year, a pipe-smoking, ski-mask-wearing revolutionary known as "Subcomandante Marcos" became the public face of an indigenous uprising in this country's south. This country, where hundreds of student protesters died in the 1968 Tlatelolco Massacre, witnessed the PAN party come to power for the first time in 2000, under Vicente Fox. This country's participation in NAFTA was opposed by the Zapatistas in its state of Chiapas. For 10 points, name this country long led by the PRI.

fields.content: In 1524, a key establishment was founded atop the ancient Mexica capital of Mexico-Tenochtitlan in this country. It later saw strife between liberales, favoring federalism, and conservadores, advocating hierarchy. This discord sparked a civil war, with figures like Francisco Villa and Emiliano Zapata leading their own forces. In 1959, this nation's Academy of Sciences was formed to unify scientific endeavors. Notably, Molina, an alumnus, became its first citizen to win a Nobel in science. This country, housing 10–12% of global biodiversity with over 200,000 species, has seen debates over its biodiversity usage since the late 20th century. For 10 points, name this North American nation.

fields.content: John Conway developed the LUX algorithm for constructing these things, in which rows of L's, U's and X's are repeatedly interchanged. A visit to Thailand inspired Simon de la Loubere to create the Siamese method for generating these constructs. These entities are called "satanic" if each of their entries are raised to an integer power and their defining properties still hold. Benjamin Franklin discovered a "semi-" type of these constructs that has order eight and an associated constant equal to 260. In the simplest of these constructs, the number five is at the center and fifteen is the sum of the rows, columns and diagonals. Sudoku was created when amateur mathematicians removed numbers from them. For 10 points, name these grids whose entries sum to a certain value.

fields.content: A square once attributed to Euler was actually published by William Beverley in 1848. It can be constructed using the medjig method, which creates a square of order 2"N" from any "N" × "N" medjig-square, with each row, column, and long diagonal summing to 3"N". This square is akin to the Lo Shu Square, but with 19 added to each number, yielding a magic constant of 72. All squares of a given order share the same moment of inertia. For M=12, a truth table results in a square with 3-nibbles per row and 12 rows. The rows and columns each total 260, and halfway they total 130, and a chess knight can touch all 64 boxes in consecutive numerical order. The Sagrada Família church in Barcelona features a 4×4 square with a magic constant of 33. This square is generated from an initial population of squares with random values. For 10 points, name this mathematical concept.
