fields.content: A 2008 University of Dundee study found that individuals exposed only to black and white media in childhood reported this phenomenon in monochrome 25% of the time. Salvador Dalí's 1944 painting "Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee around a Pomegranate a Second Before Awakening" also explores this theme. A study showed that Americans were more likely to avoid their flight if they experienced this phenomenon of their plane crashing. This term is also used broadly by the public. Coutts asserts that this phenomenon is central to a two-phase sleep process that enhances the mind's functionality during wakefulness. It primarily occurs during the REM stage of sleep, when brain activity is high. A related parasomnia disorder affecting children is night terror, which induces feelings of terror. For 10 points, name this common sleep experience.

fields.content: Established in historic "Mitteldeutschland," this entity was a communist state that emphasized scientific atheism. Western media and statesmen avoided its official name, using terms like "Ostzone" and "Sowjetische Besatzungszone." Writer Ascher Barnstone noted its citizens' resentment towards their wealthier western counterparts. It dispatched an estimated 2000 – 4000 military and security experts to Africa and had a Democratic Women's Federation in the Volkskammer. Figure skating was popular here, thanks to athletes like Katarina Witt. For 10 points, name this former European country that reunified with its western counterpart in 1990.

fields.content: The cable equation models these cells in one dimension. Agrin is required for their development. Growth factors for these cells bind to either Trks (tracks) or p75. A patch clamp experiment is done to these cells. These cells have NMDA and AMPA receptors that allow them to develop plasticity during long-term potentiation. They are stained by potassium dichromate, then silver nitrate, during a Golgi stain. fields.content: Squid cells, larger but akin to these entities, were easier to study. A technique, "double impregnation", improved their study and is still used today. These entities, varying in shape and size, are classified by morphology and function. Unlike dendrites, their axon maintains a consistent diameter. Their receptors are "excitatory", "inhibitory", or "modulatory". Camillo Golgi classified them into two types based on axon length. Sensory ones respond to stimuli and send signals to the brain. In Parkinson's disease, these entities are impaired. For 10 points, name this fundamental unit of the nervous system.

fields.content: This author wrote "Abraham should come with his axe and his wooden plate" in a poem addressed to an American soldier. This poet often wrote in green ink, which he considered the color of hope. fields.content: In 1919, this poet won third place in the Juegos Florales del Maule for "Comunión ideal." He was a senator until the Communist Party was banned under the Ley Maldita in 1948, during which time he was in hiding and his lover Urrutia shadowed him. His criticism of González Videla led to the "Yo acuso" speech, and he further explored political themes in "Canto General." After Khrushchev's Secret Speech, he admitted to contributing to Stalin's "cult of personality." Despite being barred from the U.S. for his communist ties, Arthur Miller secured him a visa. In 2011, Chile's Communist Party requested the exhumation of his remains. For 10 points, name this author of "Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair."

fields.content: This thinker calls his teacher, William of Champeaux, the "supreme master" of dialectic in an autobiographical letter that recounts how Anselm of Laon persecuted him. He argues that the mind's vices make one disposed to sin in his moral treatise Ethics, or Know Thyself. His most notable work begins with a prologue that states one should not rashly pass judgments on saints whose writings contradict each other. That work consists of 158 theological assertions and their negations. This city was the site of the 1863 Draft Riots, one of the deadliest incidents of civil unrest in American history.
The construction of the Erie Canal greatly increased this city's economic importance.
The Statue of Liberty, a gift from France, is located in this city's harbor.
For 10 points, name this city, the most populous in the United States, home to Times Square and Central Park.

fields.content: In a 1-D or 2-D crystal below the Peierls temperature, standing waves named for density and this quantity are formed. This quantity's density is multiplied by the speed of light in the time-like component of a four-vector which is symbolized J. The flux of the polarization density through a surface equals the "bound" value of this quantity enclosed within the surface. This quantity's conservation is expressed by a continuity equation derived by applying the divergence theorem to Ampere's Law. The quantization of this quantity was demonstrated in an experiment where Robert Millikan studied the motion of oil droplets. The force between "point" examples of this quantity is given by Coulomb's Law. For 10 points, what electrical quantity is thus measured in Coulombs?

fields.content: This property, fundamental to matter exhibiting electrostatic attraction or repulsion, was explored by William Gilbert in "De Magnete". Gilbert identified all electrified bodies as either vitreously or resinously electrified, associating "positive" with the former and "negative" with the latter. It is seen in "monatomic ions" and "polyatomic ions", which yield a positive or negative net value of this property. The law of "conservation of this property" ensures that an object from which a negative value is taken gains a positive value of equal magnitude, and vice versa. Fractions of this property are meaningful in contexts like capacitor charging or the fractional quantum Hall effect. For 10 points, name this property, the basic unit of which is the coulomb.

For 10 points, name this property, the basic unit of which is the coulomb.

fields.content: This dynasty unsuccessfully attempted to restore the Le Dynasty by invading Hanoi in the aftermath of the Tay Son Rebellion. This dynasty came to power by driving the peasant rebel Li Zicheng from Peking, a month after the last emperor of the previous dynasty hung himself on a tree behind the Forbidden City. fields.content: In the early 17th century, Nurhaci of the Aisin Gioro clan founded what would become the Manchu state. This clan also formed the state's ruling council and army high command. A significant event was when Li Chengdong, a Han general who had surrendered to this state, orchestrated three massacres in Jiading, causing tens of thousands of deaths. After winning Taiwan, Kangxi's forces battled over Albazin, a far eastern Russian outpost. In 1756, this state implemented the Canton System, granting monopoly trading rights to private Chinese merchants. For 10 points, name this last imperial dynasty of China.

fields.content: Giovanni Pietro Bellori, a friend of this artist, noted his birth near Les Andelys in Normandy and his Latin education. Félibien documented his extensive output, and the specific models he used are deemed insignificant. His works are housed in global collections, including the National Gallery in London and the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg. One composition features shepherds examining a tomb inscribed "Even in Arcadia I exist", interpreted as a memento mori. Another depicts a philosopher discarding a cup after seeing a man drink water with his hands. For 10 points, name this prolific French Baroque painter.

fields.content: To treat tuberculosis, bedaquiline inhibits this protein in bacteria. A subunit of this protein is composed of three subunits in a 1:2:10 stoichiometric ratio and is named for its affinity to oligomycin. In brown fat, thermogenin bypasses this protein. V-class enzymes, which catalyze the normal reverse reaction as this enzyme, acidify lysosomes. According to Paul Boyer's Nobel Prize-winning model of this protein, a ring rotates around a central stalk, acting as a molecular motor. This enzyme couples the diffusion of protons down the electrochemical gradient to oxidative phosphorylation. For 10 points, name this protein that spans the inner mitochondrial membrane at the end of the electron transport chain, which produces the "energy currency" of the cell.

fields.content: John E. Walker's group crystallized the F catalytic-domain of an enzyme, confirming Boyer's rotary-catalysis model. This enzyme, found in the thylakoid and inner mitochondrial membranes, operates differently in chloroplasts, where the proton motive force is generated by photosynthetic proteins. It changes shape to bind newly produced molecules with high affinity. This activity, linked to the creation of a certain molecule, has evolved into today's intricate versions of this enzyme. For 10 points, name this enzyme that is responsible for the synthesis of ATP.

fields.content: This protein complex's gamma subunit rotates in a manner described by the binding change mechanism proposed by Paul Boyer. The F0 portion of this complex is a proton channel that drives the rotation of the F1 portion, which synthesizes a molecule by condensing inorganic phosphate and ADP. ATP.

fields.content: At 16, this figure experienced the outbreak of World War I and later, his mother's death. He was present at the 1925 "Neue Sachlichkeit" exhibition in Mannheim, marking a new post-Expressionist movement in German arts. A year later, short stories were published under his name, closely associated with Hauptmann. He once noted that Charlie Chaplin came closer to the epic than to the dramatic theatre's requirements and downplayed the importance of a play's poetry. fields.content: The XENON research project uses a dual phase time projection chamber to search for this component, whose distribution is plotted on a NavarroFrenkWhite profile. The cusp-core problem has led to the suggestion that this component is self-interacting. Plots of orbital velocities of bodies against radial distance on a galactic rotation curve lead to the inference of this component, which Fritz Zwicky postulated after studying the Coma Cluster. Mordehai Milgrom developed MOND, or Modified Newtonian Dynamics, as an alternative to this entity. Axions are candidates for its "cold" form, while its "hot," ultra-relativistic form would be contributed from neutrinos. For 10 points, name this currently undetected hypothetical substance that might comprise most of the mass of the universe.

fields.content: Until the 1990s, simulations of halo formation showed little substructure. When galaxies first formed, baryonic matter was too hot to form gravitationally self-bound objects, necessitating the prior formation of a certain structure. This structure later merged small halos into a single virialized entity with an ellipsoidal shape and sub-halos. Observations of spiral galaxies show that rotational velocities don't decrease with distance from the galactic center. Two projects limited MACHOS to only 10% of this structure's mass. This structure makes stars appear brighter. For 10 points, name this unseen structure surrounding galaxies.

This structure makes stars appear brighter.
For 10 points, name this unseen structure surrounding galaxies.

fields.content: This structure's existence was first suggested by Jan Oort while studying the motion of nearby stars in our galaxy. The rotation curves of spiral galaxies, which do not decrease with radius as would be expected from Kepler's laws, provide evidence for this structure. It is believed to be composed of non-baryonic particles that do not interact with electromagnetic radiation, making it invisible to current detection methods. For 10 points, name this theoretical component of galaxies, a spherical region of invisible matter surrounding the visible parts.

fields.content: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's string quintet in this key is considered a companion piece to the one in G minor. Mozart's D major Flute Concerto No. 2 is a reworking of his oboe concerto, which is in this key. Both of Georges Bizet's symphonies are in this key, which Mozart used for a piano concerto best-known for its F major Andante second movement's usage in the 1967 film Elvira Madigan. The "Wedding March" from Mendelssohn's A Midsummer Night's Dream suite is in this key. Robbins Landon notes that Haydn sparingly used other keys for trumpets and timpani after 1774. The Signature Series radio program explores this key. For 10 points, name this key, which has no sharps or flats and is the tonic key of the "Ode to Joy" in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

fields.content: While searching for oil off this island's coast, Exxon drilled the world's longest borehole in 2011. After visiting a prison colony on this island, Anton Chekhov wrote his only work of non-fiction, a sociological piece criticizing the penal system. In 1983, Korean Air Lines Flight 007 was accidentally shot down off this island's western shore by the Soviet Union. This island lies east of the Strait of Tartary and north of the La Pérouse Strait. Its city of Korsakov was rebuilt as the city of Ōtomari after this island was divided in two by the Treaty of Portsmouth. The Soviet Union reclaimed this island's southern half from Japan in the last days of World War II, along with the nearby Kuril Islands. For 10 points, name this large Russian island north of Hokkaidō.

fields.content: Moneron Island and Ush Island are associated with this location, which was the site of the first production-sharing agreement with Russia. La Perouse charted the nearby Strait of Tartary and was told by locals that it was called "Tchoka". The Chinese of the Ming dynasty knew it as Kuyi, Kuwu, and later Kuye. Unlike interior east Asia, this place has year-round precipitation peaking in autumn. The Tym river, navigable by rafts and light boats, flows into the Sea of Okhotsk from here. Its flora includes cloudberry, cranberry, crowberry, and Spiraea. For 10 points, name this North Pacific island of Russia.

fields.content: This island was the setting for the novel "Dersu Uzala," which was later adapted into an Academy Award-winning film by Akira Kurosawa. The southern part of this island was ceded to Japan after the Russo-Japanese War, but was reclaimed by the Soviet Union after World War II. fields.content: Long before Quine, this philosopher used a distinction between "walking" and "hurrying" to illustrate the indeterminacy of meaning in De Magistro. This man's claim that he learned to speak by inferring the names of things is critiqued at the opening of Wittgenstein's Philosophical Investigations. This philosopher, who proposed a psychological analogy for the Trinity, found himself unable to explain time and concluded that it was a distension of the mind, which God lies beyond. He coined the term "just war" in a work whose title construct triumphs over the Earthly City. He was a Neoplatonist and a Manichaean before eventually converting to Christianity. fields.content: This figure admired Ambrose's oratory skills and, like other Church Fathers, condemned induced abortion, distinguishing between early and later stages. Before the Council of Ephesus, he defended the Virgin Mary as the Mother of God, full of grace due to her virginity. He proposed that "only a will that was once free can be subjected to sin's corruption," and is known for "City of God" 14.23. The Christian rock band Disciple honored him in their 2010 track "The Ballad of St. Augustine". For 10 points, name this early Christian theologian and philosopher whose writings shaped Western Christianity and philosophy.

fields.content: This institution rose to national prominence under Charles William Eliot, who published its namesake "Classics" series that ran 50 volumes. George Vaillant tracked members of this institution over 75 years in the longitudinal Grant Study. This location lends its name to a computer architecture used by Howard Aiken's Mark I (one). Robert Putnam, Stephen Walt, and Joseph Nye are members of this institution's John F. Kennedy School of Government, named for an alumnus. fields.content: Formed in 1636 by the Massachusetts Bay Colony, this institution saw rapid growth as it expanded its undergraduate College and initiated graduate schools. After the deaths of the Hollis Professor of Divinity and its president in the early 1800s, a struggle ensued over their replacements. It began admitting women to its graduate schools in the late 19th century, and during WWII, Radcliffe College students started attending its classes. Recently, it enrolled over 20,000 students across undergraduate, graduate, and professional programs. Its Pusey Library houses America's oldest collection of maps and atlases. Film critic Paul Sherman associated it with tradition and stuffiness. For 10 points, name this Ivy League university in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

fields.content: In the first line of a poem, this character cries "Courage!" and claims that "this mounting wave will roll us shoreward soon." This character then arrives in a "land in which it seemed always afternoon." Describing his son, this character concludes, "He works his work, I mine." In the opening of another poem, this character notes that "I am become a name" and regrets having to "mete and dole unequal laws unto a savage race." In that poem, this character decides "to sail beyond the sunset," even though he is not "that strength that in old days moved earth and heaven." For 10 points, identify this unnamed leader in Tennyson's "The Lotos-eaters" who also narrates a dramatic monologue ending with his resolution to "strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield."

fields.content: John Sterling, a fellow Cambridge Apostle, lauded this work in the "Quarterly Review" in 1842. The author revealed that it was written under a sense of loss and the belief that life must be fought to the end. Critic Chiasson views it as "intractable" in its author's canon, but believes its meaning becomes clear when seen as a depiction of the author's belief that disregarding religious sanctions leads to a repudiation of responsibility. This work is often used to exemplify the dramatic monologue form. For 10 points, name this poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson.

fields.content: The von Neumann (NOY-mahn) hierarchy is defined using transfinite recursion starting with this mathematical construct. For any topological space, this entity and the whole space will always have the property of being "clopen," or being open and closed simultaneously. The Cartesian product of any object A with this other object will always itself yield this object. In a vacuous truth, the universal quantifier is applied to this entity. The power set always includes this construct, which has a cardinality of zero. The intersection of two disjoint sets yields this object, and it is always the subset of any given set. A circle with a slash through it represents, for 10 points, what set that contains no elements and is sometimes called the "null set?"

fields.content: In Zermelo set theory, an axiom assures the existence of a certain concept, with its uniqueness derived from the axiom of extensionality. Some axiomatic set theories include an axiom for it, while others deduce its existence. Darling noted the contrast of this concept in mathematical rephrasing of two statements about "nothing". The product of its elements is considered one, the identity element for multiplication. Historically, it was symbolized by "formula_3", but common notations now include "formula_1", "∅", and "formula_2". Statements beginning "for every element of formula_2" make no substantive claim, and "every" element "x" of formula_2 belongs to "A". For 10 points, name this mathematical concept with no elements.

fields.content: A character in this novel asks to be brought a copy of Cherbuliez's Paule Méré, whose plot mirrors that of this work. Another character in this novel talks about a doctor in Schenectady, Mr. Davis, who sought to cure her dyspepsia. Mrs. Costello, the aunt of this novel's protagonist, is shocked that her nephew accompanies the title character from Vevey to the Chateau de Chillon. Mrs. Walker ostracizes the title character because she walks about Rome too much with Italian men like Mr. Giovanelli, and that character eventually contracts malaria after a nighttime visit to the Colosseum. The plot thickens in Rome, where the protagonist and Winterbourne encounter each other in Mrs. Walker's parlor. The protagonist's stark contrast with Winterbourne is a key theme. A 1974 film adaptation starred Cybill Shepherd as the lead, Barry Brown as Winterbourne, and Eileen Brennan as Mrs. Walker. For 10 points, name this Henry James novella.

fields.content: First attested in Richard Eden's 1555 translation of Duarte Barbosa's journal, this entity's name was applied to the area around Luoyi during the Eastern Zhou, then to the Central Plain, and occasionally for the state under the Qing. The Shang dynasty ruled its eastern Yellow River plain from the 17th to the 11th century. Today, it governs 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, four municipalities, and two special administrative regions, while also claiming Taiwan. In 2011, it was the world's third-largest pharmaceutical supplier, but counterfeit medications have plagued its population. A culture of merit and examinations are greatly valued here. This country, known for its kiwi bird and as the filming location for The Lord of the Rings, is led from its capital, Wellington. For 10 points, name this island nation in the southwestern Pacific Ocean.
clue_list: The first recorded European to sight this country was Abel Tasman, who was attacked by Māori in Golden Bay and never actually landed.
This country's South Island is home to the Southern Alps, which includes the highest peak, Aoraki/Mount Cook.
The indigenous Māori people signed the Treaty of Waitangi with the British in 1840, ceding sovereignty to Queen Victoria while retaining territorial rights.
This country, known for its kiwi bird and as the filming location for The Lord of the Rings, is led from its capital, Wellington.
For 10 points, name this island nation in the southwestern Pacific Ocean.

fields.content: These people give a sermon called a samavasarana (suh-MOV-suh-RUN) after reaching the thirteenth gunasthana (GOON-sthah-nah). Most of these figures died at a pilgrimage site called Samet Shikhar (sa-MET shee-CUR). Five auspicious events, called the panch kalyanak ("PUNCH" cull-YAH-nuk), occur during the lifetimes of these people, including their attainment of kevaljnana (KEH-vul-NYAN), or perfect knowledge. When these people are conceived, their mothers have a vivid series of fourteen dreams. One of these people, Mallinath, was a woman according to Shvetambaras (SHVEH-tum-burrs). These people are distinguished from other siddhas (SIH-dhahs) by their goal of helping others reach moksha. Twenty-four of these people are born during each half of the Jain time-cycle. For 10 points, name these liberators in Jainism, the most recent of which was Mahavira.

fields.content: Rishabhanatha, the first of these figures, is credited for organising humans to live harmoniously in society. Jain tradition states these figures were royal in their final lives, with details of their previous lives recorded. History notes the existence of Mahavira and his predecessor, Parshvanatha, the twenty-third of these figures. 20 of these figures attained "moksha" on mount Shikharji, in Jharkhand. Digambara images of these figures are naked, while Svetambara ones are clothed and decorated. They dwell within the realm of their Soul, free of "kashayas", inner passions, and desires. Revered by Jains, their grace is said to be available to all beings. The names of the next 24 of these figures, to be born in "utsarpinī" age, are recorded. For 10 points, name this spiritual role in Jainism.

The names of the next 24 of these figures, to be born in "utsarpinī" age, are recorded.
For 10 points, name this spiritual role in Jainism.

fields.content: A figure of this type is often depicted with a lion symbol and is known as Mahavira, who is the last of these figures in the current time cycle. Another figure of this type, Rishabhanatha, is often depicted with a bull and is considered the first of these figures in the present time cycle. These figures are believed to have achieved liberation and guide others on the path to liberation. They are central figures in a religion that emphasizes non-violence and asceticism. For 10 points, name these spiritual teachers in Jainism.

fields.content: In a story titled for this literary form, the protagonist steals letters written between the dogs Meggy and Fidel. In a work in this form, the narrator expresses a desire to have a girlfriend after her request to touch the breasts of her friend Jacque is rejected. In a story titled for this literary form, a newspaper article about a vacancy on the Spanish throne leads the narrator to think he is Ferdinand VIII. Poprishchin creates one of these works "of a madman" in a story by Nikolai Gogol. A work in this form is given the name "Kitty" by its author, who obsesses over Peter van Pels while living in the Secret Annex. For 10 points, identify this type of book, one of which was written in Amsterdam by Anne Frank.

fields.content: The oldest known examples of this document come from Middle Eastern and East Asian cultures, with Marcus Aurelius' "Meditations" displaying many of its characteristics. In the 17th century, John Evelyn and Samuel Pepys kept notable examples, providing eyewitness accounts of events like the Great Plague and the Great Fire of London. Since the 19th century, their publication has become common, especially among politicians and artists. In the late 20th-century, British politicians like Richard Crossman, Tony Benn, and Alan Clark published theirs, with Clark's being notably indiscreet. The internet has brought previously unpublished ones to light, such as Michael Shiner's, and services like Open Diary and LiveJournal have streamlined their online publishing. They've even been used in literature, like in the "Diaries of Adrian Mole". For 10 points, name this record, often kept daily, that documents personal experiences and thoughts.

For 10 points, name this record, often kept daily, that documents personal experiences and thoughts.

fields.content: Diana Puntar's "homemade futurist" sculpture Less Than Day, Or Night was inspired by this artist's work. Carlo Barsotti established the park named for this man in New York City, which is where Ettore Ximenes's massive sculpture of him resides. A sculpture inspired by the philosophy of this person quotes Michelangelo's portrait of Lorenzo Medici and was originally created to sit in front of the other sculptures Eternal Springtime and I Am Beautiful. This man's writings inspired a sculptural complex in which the sculpture The Three Graces can be seen at its top. A depiction of Ugolino, gnawing at his fingers, was inspired by the writings of this man. The Thinker and The Gates of Hell were inspired by, for 10 points, what Italian author's The Divine Comedy?

fields.content: Born in the Republic of Florence, this figure was embroiled in the Guelph–Ghibelline conflict due to his family's loyalties to the Guelphs. His early life involved common practices like contractually formalized marriages. He participated in failed attempts by the White Guelphs to regain power, and despite a general pardon by Baldo d'Aguglione, he remained in exile until a posthumous pardon in 2008. His unique expression of love is evident in his works, and studies have deduced his influence on painting and music from "Vita Nuova" and the "Comedy." For 10 points, name this author of the Divine Comedy.

fields.content: This author's early work, La Vita Nuova, is a collection of 31 poems interspersed with prose commentary detailing his love for Beatrice Portinari. This author's political treatise, De Monarchia, argues for a universal monarchy under the Holy Roman Emperor. In a work by this author, the protagonist is guided through Hell and Purgatory by the Roman poet Virgil. The protagonist of that work by this author finally reaches Paradise, where he is reunited with Beatrice. For 10 points, name this Italian author of The Divine Comedy.

fields.content: This protein makes its first "jump" to the PPT site after it originally binds to the PBS sequence. Packaging cell lines replace this protein's gene with the gene of interest. The azide derivative of thymidine inhibits this protein. The Pol gene encodes integrase and this protein. It has a ribonuclease H domain to cut out U5 and R regions from the long terminal repeats. A variant of this enzyme is encoded by telomerase. Class I transposons encode this protein. This enzyme, which opposes the direction asserted by the central dogma of molecular biology, is used to generate cDNA libraries from ssRNA. This enzyme is encoded by retroviral and lentiviral genomes. For 10 points, name this enzyme that HIV uses to convert RNA to DNA.

For 10 points, name this enzyme that HIV uses to convert RNA to DNA.

fields.content: The RNA 5’end to the PBS site is U5, and the 3’ end is the leader, a peculiar arrangement as this enzyme synthesizes DNA from the 3’ end of the primer in the 5’ to 3’ direction. This repositioning requires DNA polymerase, ribonuclease H, and polynucleotide unwinding. The enzyme also aids in replicating chromosome ends and mobile genetic elements. It converts edited RNA back into DNA for genome incorporation and is used by HIV to infect humans. Commercial versions by Promega have error rates of 1 in 17,000 bases for AMV and 1 in 30,000 for M-MLV. It's used to produce insulin, bypassing traditional sources like pig pancreas. Its discovery led to a shared 1975 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. For 10 points, name this enzyme that creates single-stranded DNA from an RNA template.

fields.content: This enzyme was first discovered in studies of replication of the Moloney murine leukemia virus. It is responsible for the conversion of RNA into DNA, a process that contradicts the central dogma of molecular biology. This enzyme is a key component in the life cycle of retroviruses, including one that causes a disease first clinically observed in the 1980s. That disease, which can be managed with antiretroviral therapy, is caused by a virus that uses this enzyme to integrate its genome into the host's DNA. For 10 points, name this enzyme crucial to the replication of HIV.

fields.content: A revolting drink made from chickpeas known as "national coffee" was drunk by citizens of this government. After the end of this government, women accused of "horizontal collaboration" had their heads shaved during public shamings. During this government's tenure, the founder of the underground paper Combat was shot by the paramilitary Milice (mil-LEASE) force. Many of this government's ships were destroyed in an attack on Mers-el-Kebir by the British and in a scuttling of the fleet after the armistice army was disbanded. This government adopted the slogan of "Work, family, fatherland." This government was headed by Prime Minister Pierre Laval and the hero of the Battle of Verdun, Philippe Petain. For 10 points, name this pro-German French government during World War II.

fields.content: Paxton's research indicates that 14,000 Jews died in French concentration camps under a regime that opposed "modern" social trends and sought "national regeneration" to align with traditional Catholicism. This regime, marked by anti-British propaganda like Henri Béraud's 1940 pamphlet, faced opposition from the Free French's Operation Marie and a British blockade. The American and British invasion of French North Africa, known as Operation Torch, further challenged this regime. A "national unanimity" cabinet uniting French Resistance factions re-established a provisional French Republic, seemingly restoring continuity with the Third Republic. This regime disappeared in late 1944 when the Allies occupied all of France. For 10 points, name this World War II-era French government.

fields.content: A leader of this regime was the author of the 1934 book "The Decadence," which criticized the Treaty of Versailles. This regime's leader, who was a World War I hero at the Battle of Verdun, was known as the "Lion of Verdun." This regime, which was established after the signing of an armistice in a namesake city, collaborated with Nazi Germany and implemented anti-Semitic laws known as the "Statutes on Jews." fields.content: The first play published by an Englishwoman is a 1613 "Tragedy" of a queen of this group by Elizabeth Cary. One of these people disguises himself as a French lute player to kill his blackmailer and the courtesan Bellarmina with poisoned flowers. That member of this group claims "As for myself, I walk abroad a-nights and kill sick people groaning under walls." Calymath is saved from the plans of one of them when Governor Ferneze opens a trap door. A member of this religious group buys the slave Ithamore, whom he sends to poison the residents of a nunnery, and dies in a boiling cauldron. For 10 points, name this religious group which Barrabas belongs to in a Christopher Marlowe play set in Malta and which also includes The Merchant of Venice's moneylender Shylock.

fields.content: Historian Shaye J. D. Cohen noted that the Bible determined the status of mixed marriages' offspring patrilineally, impacting this group's demographics. Behar "et al." studied this group's genetic lineage. The Hebrew term for this group, Yhudi, stresses the final syllable in Israeli Hebrew. Interreligious marriage rates for this group vary globally, from just under 50% in the U.S. to as low as 10% in Australia and Mexico. The German word "Jude" and adjective "jüdisch" (Jewish) originated the term "Yiddish", associated with this group. They constitute 75.4% of Israel's population, or 6 million people. Israel's early years saw mass immigration of Holocaust survivors and members of this group fleeing Arab lands. Israel is the only nation where this group forms the majority. For 10 points, name this religious group.

fields.content: Two thieves rode on paper sculptures of these animals to steal a pearl guarded by one on Mount Kinabalu. In Korean mythology, imugi often sought to become fullfledged examples of these creatures. Another of these animals tells the Jade Emperor that it didn't win the Great Race because it stopped to help humanity. In a story from Fengshen Yanyi, Nezha feuds with Ao Guang, one of the four "kings" of these creatures who rule over the four seas. An azure one of these creatures represents the east and the spring, and a hornless yellow one was identified with the Emperor. The fenghuang, or phoenix, is the yin counterpart to this creature's yang. For 10 points, name these legendary animals, which are usually more serpentine in China than their Western counterparts.

fields.content: Tradition depicts this creature as a composite of nine animals, each with unique imagery. Slovenian folklorist Johann Weikhard von Valvasor linked it to the subterranean salamander, the Olm. The Drukpa Lineage, originating in Tibet, adopted a variant of this creature, the druk, as an emblem. In Russia, it often has heads in multiples of three. It features prominently in J.R.R. Tolkien's works. St George's slaying of this creature, symbolizing Satan, adorns Moscow's coat of arms. The European version has bat-like wings. For 10 points, name this mythical beast often linked with fire.

fields.content: A creature of this type named Fafnir was transformed from a dwarf into this creature after being cursed by Andvari's ring and gold in Norse mythology. In a different culture, a creature of this type named Ladon was tasked with guarding the golden apples in the Garden of the Hesperides. Another creature of this type, named Smaug, hoards a vast treasure in the Lonely Mountain in a novel by J.R.R. Tolkien. fields.content: In this technique, overtones are false signals that appear at twice the amount of a very strong signal. Aldehydes are easily identified by this technique due to bumps on the right hand side of the alkane peak. This technique detects stretching and scissoring of bonds in water molecules. Its results are plotted in a wavenumber vs. transmittance graph that typically contains a large peak around 3000 indicating carbon-hydrogen bonds. Solid samples for it can be mixed with potassium bromide and pressed to form a transparent disk. With this technique, every molecule has a unique signature between 500 and 1500 inverse centimeters called the fingerprint region. For 10 points, name this technique that probes samples using light at a wavelength longer than visible light.

fields.content: In 1934, Richard Badger proposed a rule linking bond strength to vibrational mode frequency. This method can be used in a nonlinear two-dimensional manner, akin to COSY or NOESY. It has been used to determine the O-O stretching frequency of oxyhemocyanin, found to be 832 and 788 reciprocal centimeters. The pathlength of the sample cell in this technique depends on the compound's concentration. It identifies which bond deformations correspond to which frequencies. The sample can be solid, liquid, or gas. This method also controls for variables like compound concentration and sample cell pathlength. For 10 points, name this technique involving the interaction of matter with infrared radiation.

fields.content: This technique was used by John M. Cowley to discover the "forbidden" spectral lines of the OH radical in the interstellar medium. The "fingerprint region" in this technique is typically found between 1500 and 500 cm^-1. This technique is often used to identify functional groups in organic compounds, such as carbonyl groups, which absorb strongly in this technique at around 1700 cm^-1. The Beer-Lambert law is often used to interpret the results of this technique. For 10 points, name this spectroscopic technique that measures the absorption of light in the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

This technique is often used to identify functional groups in organic compounds, such as carbonyl groups, which absorb strongly in this technique at around 1700 cm^-1.
The Beer-Lambert law is often used to interpret the results of this technique.
For 10 points, name this spectroscopic technique that measures the absorption of light in the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

fields.content: A quantity named for this man is the proportionality constant between the product of the total angular momentum, Lande g factor, and one over the reduced Planck constant and the magnetic moment of the atom. De Broglie re-derived this man's restraints on angular momentum as a standing wave with an integer number of periods around a circular orbit. The electron has a magnetic moment of roughly one in units of this man's namesake magneton, which is expressed in terms of electron mass and h-bar. The quantity "a-sub-naught" is part of this man's namesake model, which was able to successfully reproduce the Rydberg formula with transitions between its energy levels. For 10 points, name this early quantum physicist who created a fixed-orbit model of the atom.

fields.content: After this dynasty fell into decline, it briefly became a vassal to the Buyid emirs in Shiraz. Around the same time, the Samanids and the Ghaznavids broke away from this dynasty in Khorasan. It came to power in a revolution led by the populist general Abu Muslim, whom this dynasty quickly murdered afterwards. The Barmakid family from Bactria wielded much influence in this dynasty's early years. To avoid shedding royal blood, this dynasty's last king was rolled up in a carpet and stomped to death by horses. This caliphate lost most of its territory to the Fatimids and Seljuk Turks in the 10th century. In 1258, Hulagu Khan sacked its capital of Baghdad. For 10 points, name this caliphate that succeeded the Umayyads.

fields.content: In 1137 AH, Shaikh Mohamed Saeed rallied support for a military force within a caliphate that regained strength after the Buyids' decline. However, by the late 8th century, it had alienated Arab "mawali" and Iranian bureaucrats, losing authority over regions like Al-Andalus and Egypt to other dynasties. Al-Mutawakkil's troops were annihilated in Anatolia in 863. Over time, the caliphs became ceremonial figures as viziers gained power and a Persian bureaucracy replaced the Arab aristocracy. This caliphate saw advancements in paper making, with assembly-line methods for hand-copying manuscripts. Its cultural growth ended abruptly in 1258 with the sack of Baghdad by the Mongols. It contributed significantly to Islamic philosophy, not necessarily religious or exclusively Muslim. For 10 points, name this caliphate that succeeded the Umayyads.

A constitutional referendum that he supports will reduce the power of his country's Senate. In a Times op-ed, this man argued that the EU's Triton initiative was pitiful compared to his country's Mare Nostrum program. This youngest PM in his country's history tweeted, "Stay calm! Nobody wants your job" to his predecessor, Enrico Letta. He backed the 2015 presidential candidacy of Sergio Mattarella. fields.content: This individual met with Putin and Medvedev in Moscow and discussed the Ukrainian crisis and civil wars in Libya and Syria at the G-20 summit. They also met with Tony Blair, whom they admired, and prioritized "long-overdue" labour market reform upon assuming office. Their party supported the "Jobs Act" despite internal disagreements. During their tenure, migrant arrivals by sea increased by 296% in 2014. They extended their country's military presence in Afghanistan in 2015 to combat Islamist forces. fields.content: The Boggs-Fallon Bill implemented a proposal to pay for 90% of the cost of this system using bonds and taxes, which was put forth by a committee led by Lucius Clay. The withholding of funds for use on this system from states with an under-21 drinking age led to the case South Dakota v. Dole. Lady Bird Johnson's call to clean up this system inspired a namesake 1965 Beautification Act. An act passed during the 1973 energy crisis placed a limit for users of this system that was repealed in 1995. The creation of this system contributed to "white flight" by allowing residents of the suburbs to travel quickly to urban jobs. For 10 points, the Autobahn inspired Dwight Eisenhower to champion the creation of what network of large roads?

fields.content: Interstate Highways, part of the Strategic Highway Network, often label exit numbers sequentially in northeastern states. For instance, I-87's exits from Albany to the Canadian border are numbered 1 to 44. Mileage markers on the Jane Addams Memorial Tollway start from O'Hare International Airport. States like Georgia and Maine have renumbered their highways in 2000 and 2004 respectively. The ongoing Pennsylvania Turnpike/Interstate 95 Interchange Project exemplifies the system's continuous development. For 10 points, name this network of controlled-access highways in the National Highway System.

fields.content: A Beethoven piece in this genre begins with an Allegro assai movement in F minor and 12/8 time. An A major chord slowly arpeggiated over two octaves begins a D minor piece of this type whose opening repeatedly alternates tempos between Largo and Allegro. Brahms's F minor third piece in this genre repeatedly quotes the "fate motif" from Beethoven's fifth. Beethoven wrote a C minor piece in this genre best known for its A-flat major Adagio cantabile second movement; his other pieces of this type include Tempest and Appassionata. The opening Adagio sostenuto movement of a piece in this genre in C-sharp minor was compared to nighttime reflections on Lake Lucerne. fields.content: Schubert's Wanderer Fantasie of 1822 introduced thematic transformation, a concept Franz Liszt used in his "three-movements-in-one" Sonata in B minor. This composition form, favored by the younger Schubert, thrived in the 19th and 20th centuries. Despite the Romantic era's progression, these works persisted, though in fewer numbers, as they competed with shorter, more Romantic-style genres. A key figure in this genre is known as "The Father of the Pianoforte". For 10 points, name this type of composition typically for a solo instrument, specifically the piano.

fields.content: Upon hearing a gunshot, a witness reported the perpetrator shouting something like "Freedom!" The perpetrator later wrote, "What an excellent chance I had, if I wished, to kill the President on Inauguration day!" Boston Corbett, a sergeant, shot the perpetrator, severing his spinal cord with a bullet wound in "the back of the head about an inch below the spot where his [the perpetrator's] shot had entered the head of Mr. Lincoln". This occurred when the U.S. had just recognized Liberia and Haiti in 1862, and the Confederacy was crumbling. The victim was 56 years old. His body was viewed by millions en route to the Lincoln Tomb. This event has been widely studied, especially in relation to the victim's death. For 10 points, name this tragic event in American history.

A major reconstruction left only its outer walls, erasing Baumgarten's 1960s modifications. Visitors can still see Soviet graffiti on preserved walls and part of the roof, featuring slogans like "Hitler kaputt". This graffiti symbolizes the USSR's victory over Germany. Otto Lessing contributed to its decorative elements.
A major reconstruction left only its outer walls, erasing Baumgarten's 1960s modifications.
Visitors can still see Soviet graffiti on preserved walls and part of the roof, featuring slogans like "Hitler kaputt".
This graffiti symbolizes the USSR's victory over Germany.
The building's glass dome offers a panoramic view of Berlin.
For 10 points, name this historic edifice that once housed the German Empire's parliament.

fields.content: This building's architect, Paul Wallot, designed it in a Neo-Renaissance style and included a large glass dome, which was later replaced by Norman Foster after it was destroyed. This building was the site of a 1933 fire, which the Nazis used as a pretext to suspend civil liberties and increase their power. It was heavily damaged during World War II and remained unused during the Cold War when the wall divided the city. For 10 points, name this building, which since 1999 has housed the German Bundestag, located in Berlin.
clue_list: This building's architect, Paul Wallot, designed it in a Neo-Renaissance style and included a large glass dome, which was later replaced by Norman Foster after it was destroyed.

For 10 points, name this building, which since 1999 has housed the German Bundestag, located in Berlin.

fields.content: This archipelago contains a series of stone terraces known as the Pyramids of Güímar (gwee-MAR), which were enthusiastically studied by Thor Heyerdahl. This archipelago's island of La Gomera is known for the Silbo Gomero, a whistled language used to communicate across long distances by its native Guanche people. In 1977, the worst accident in aviation history occurred when two Boeing 747s collided on a runway on its island of Tenerife. In 1936, Francisco Franco was appointed General Commandant of these islands, which sit just off the western coast of Morocco. They are situated south of the Azores and north of the Cape Verde Islands. For 10 points, name these Spanish islands in the Atlantic that are actually named for their dogs, not a type of bird.

fields.content: Two observatories, Teide and Roque de los Muchachos, are located on this archipelago where Béthencourt established a base on La Gomera. Its time zone is one hour behind mainland Spain and matches that of the UK, Ireland, and Portugal. The archipelago, with a total area of 7,493 square kilometers, had a sugar-based economy that competed with Spain's American colonies. It suffered a severe attack in 1599 during the Dutch Revolt. For 10 points, name this Spanish archipelago off Africa's northwest coast.

fields.content: The indigenous people of this location, known as the Guanches, were known for their unique whistling language, Silbo Gomero. This archipelago is home to the world's third largest volcano, Mount Teide, located in its largest island. Christopher Columbus stopped at this location in 1492 on his first voyage to the New World. Known for its black and white sand beaches, this location is a popular tourist destination off the northwest coast of Africa. For 10 points, name this Spanish archipelago.

fields.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth states that Julius Caesar had one of these objects called Crocea Mors. Svafrlami forced the dwarves Dvalinn and Durin to create one of these objects for him. Rainbows were produced by one of these items owned by Fergus mac Roich. Another of these objects was reconstructed by Regin long after it was removed from Barnstokkr by Sigmund. The cursed Tyrfing, the Caladbolg, and Gram are all examples of these objects, another of which is thrown into a lake by Sir Bedivere. Freyr owned one of these objects that could fight of its own volition, while the body of Orochi produced one called Kusanagi. In his youth, King Arthur pulled one of these objects from a stone. For 10 points, name this kind of weapon exemplified by Excalibur.

fields.content: From the late 3rd millennium BC, longer blades were crafted in the Middle East, evolving from the dagger. The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea notes these items of Indian iron and steel exported to Greece. The Khanda, a variant of this object, is prevalent in Hindu, Buddhist, and Sikh contexts. In the Ottoman Empire, the curved Yatagan, another form of this object, was used from the mid-16th century. During Europe's Renaissance, infantry used the side-version of this object in warfare. This design influenced the civilian rapier, but remained in use throughout the rapier's era. In the 15th and 16th centuries, Japanese samurai's need for close-quarters combat led to the modern katana, a pinnacle in the crafting of this object. Since Roman times in Europe, its use, seen as honourable, was a privilege for the nobility and upper classes. For 10 points, name this weapon of nobility and samurai.

Since Roman times in Europe, its use, seen as honourable, was a privilege for the nobility and upper classes.
For 10 points, name this weapon of nobility and samurai.

fields.content: This object was used in a ritual called the Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi, which is one of the three Imperial Regalia of Japan. A legendary one of these objects, named Durendal, was said to contain within its golden hilt a tooth of Saint Peter and hair of Saint Denis. Another of these objects, named Excalibur, was given to a king by the Lady of the Lake. For 10 points, name this weapon that, in a famous Arthurian legend, was pulled from a stone to signify the rightful king of Britain.
clue_list: This object was used in a ritual called the Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi, which is one of the three Imperial Regalia of Japan.
A legendary one of these objects, named Durendal, was said to contain within its golden hilt a tooth of Saint Peter and hair of Saint Denis.

fields.content: As a young man, the historian Arnold Toynbee was tasked by the British government with collecting evidence about this event. This event began in earnest after deserters were blamed for a loss at the Battle of Sarikamish, shortly after which 250 intellectuals were arrested and deported from the capital. Ambassador Henry Morgenthau reported on resistance to this event in the city of Van. Many people were marched through the desert to Deir ez-Zor during this event with the justification of keeping them away from front-line fighting. Article 301 has been used to prosecute people who discuss this event, which may have killed 1.5 million people. For 10 points, name this event in which large numbers of Christians were systematically killed during World War I by the Turks.

fields.content: Before World War I, Danish philologist Johannes Østrup met with Young Turk leaders. Later, Mazhar reported on the extensive plunder of Armenian property in the kaza district, and noted the impossibility of coexistence between Armenians and Turks. This tension culminated in the execution of many Armenian recruits by Turkish gangs. In recent years, this event has been recognized as a "bona fide" historical occurrence by twenty-nine countries and forty-three U.S. states. In 2015, Russia introduced a bill penalizing its denial. For 10 points, name this mass killing of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman Empire.

fields.content: The memoir "Black Dog of Fate" by Peter Balakian recounts the experiences of this event, which was also the subject of the novel "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh" by Franz Werfel. The denial of this event led to the assassination of Talaat Pasha by Soghomon Tehlirian in Berlin. The U.S. ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, Henry Morgenthau Sr., reported extensively on this event, which was orchestrated by the Young Turks during World War I. For 10 points, name this mass killing of an ethnic group in the Ottoman Empire.

fields.content: A long essay by Arnold Bennett about the literary type of this concept discusses "How to Read a Classic" and "The Question of Style." This term denotes a social phenomena whose dominant examples inflict symbolic violence according to Distinction, Pierre Bourdieu's "social critique of the judgement of [this]." Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin (john on-TELM bree-YOTT sah-vah-RANN) wrote about "The Physiology" of another form of this concept in a series of aphoristic essays that pioneered molecular gastronomy. The Latin saying "de gustibus non est disputandum" suggests there can be "no disputes" about this concept. Fungiform papillae underlie receptors for the sensation known by this term, which includes "umami" as one of its five components. For 10 points, name this sense that is detected with the tongue.

For 10 points, name this sense that is detected with the tongue.

fields.content: Certain substances can activate cold trigeminal receptors even when not cold. Humans can detect sucrose at an average threshold of 10 millimoles per liter. Many medicines taste bitter when chewed, as the gustatory system often interprets these as poisons. Researchers suggest that complex flavors are interpreted by the brain examining neuron response patterns. This sense also responds to amino acids in proteins, which are crucial for bodily functions. Some umami receptors respond to glutamate like sweet ones do to sugar. Philosophically, this sense is subjective and hard to define, especially regarding personal preferences. For 10 points, name this sense that perceives flavors.
clue_list: Certain substances can activate cold trigeminal receptors even when not cold.
Humans can detect sucrose at an average threshold of 10 millimoles per liter.
Many medicines taste bitter when chewed, as the gustatory system often interprets these as poisons.
Researchers suggest that complex flavors are interpreted by the brain examining neuron response patterns.
This sense also responds to amino acids in proteins, which are crucial for bodily functions.
Some umami receptors respond to glutamate like sweet ones do to sugar.
Philosophically, this sense is subjective and hard to define, especially regarding personal preferences.
For 10 points, name this sense that perceives flavors.

fields.content: This sense is mediated by specialized cells known as type II cells, which release ATP to activate afferent nerves. The "umami" category of this sense is triggered by the presence of glutamate. The tongue, the primary organ for this sense, is covered in small bumps called papillae, which contain the taste buds. This sense, along with smell, significantly contributes to the perception of flavor in food. For 10 points, name this sense that allows us to perceive sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.
clue_list: This sense is mediated by specialized cells known as type II cells, which release ATP to activate afferent nerves.
The "umami" category of this sense is triggered by the presence of glutamate.
The tongue, the primary organ for this sense, is covered in small bumps called papillae, which contain the taste buds.
This sense, along with smell, significantly contributes to the perception of flavor in food.
For 10 points, name this sense that allows us to perceive sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.

fields.content: In a poem by this author, a boy hears the "crackle of small lice dying" as "two charming older sisters" pick through his hair. This poet wrote "I sat Beauty on my lap...and I roughed her up" in a poem beginning "A while back, if I remember right, my life was one long party." The speaker of a poem by this author exclaims "I long for Europe with its aged old parapets!" and recalls how some men were nailed to stakes by "gaudy redskins." In a poem by this author, a dialogue between a Hellish Husband and a Foolish Virgin and a section titled "Alchemy of the Word" make up two "Deliriums." One of his poems is narrated by the title drifting vessel. For 10 points, name this French poet of "The Drunken Boat" and A Season in Hell who had a turbulent affair with Paul Verlaine.

fields.content: In 1862, this figure's family moved to the Cours d'Orléans, where his mother pushed for academic success. He was influenced by Charles Baudelaire and contributed to Symbolism with works like "A Season in Hell". After being arrested at the Gare du Nord and jailed in Mazas Prison, he published his "Report on the Ogaden" in 1884. His life inspired Nelo Risi's film "Una stagione all'inferno" and Lorenzo Ferrero's opera "Rimbaud, ou le fils du soleil". For 10 points, name this French poet central to Symbolism.

fields.content: This author wrote a poem in which the speaker describes a "green carriage" with "blue, red, and green cushions" and a "hideous tableau" in the sky. This author of "The Drunken Boat" wrote a prose poem collection that includes "Morning of Drunkenness" and "Farewell." This author of A Season in Hell wrote a poem in which the speaker sees vowels as colors. For 10 points, name this French Symbolist poet who wrote "Voyelles" and was the lover of Paul Verlaine.

fields.content: In this country, the GOU secret society led a 1943 coup to overthrow Ramon Castillo, ending its "Infamous Decade". The "Triple A" death squad was founded in this country shortly after right-wing snipers perpetrated a 1973 massacre at the Ezeiza Airport against the left-wing Montoneros. During this country's "National Reorganization Process", thousands of desaparecidos were kidnapped and killed by the government of Jorge Videla. A leader of this country was supported by the descamisados, or "shirtless ones", and was succeeded in 1974 by his wife Isabel. The Dirty War was a period of political repression in this country that began after the death of its president Juan Peron. For 10 points, name this country that lost the Falklands War to Britain.

fields.content: Rhodochrosite, a manganese carbonate mineral, is the national gemstone of this country. Its architecture, influenced by Spanish Baroque, is seen in the "Rioplatense" style at sites like San Ignacio Miní and the Cathedral of Córdoba. The 1994 Constitutional Amendment allowed Menem to serve a second term, but a crisis led to Eduardo Duhalde's appointment as acting president, who ended Menem's fixed exchange rate. Its railway system has four incompatible gauges, forcing most interregional freight to pass through Buenos Aires. A small number of its inhabitants are Middle Eastern-origin Muslims. For 10 points, name this South American country.

A political movement in this country, known as the Radical Civic Union, was led by Hipólito Yrigoyen and Arturo Illia. This country's most famous political couple, Juan and Eva, led a populist movement known as Peronism. The Dirty War, a period of state terrorism, occurred in this country from 1976 to 1983. For 10 points, name this South American country, the birthplace of tango and home to Buenos Aires.
